Question: 1. You grow a bacterial culture in a media containing N15 and transfer it to a media with N14. After two rounds of replication you perform a CsCl density gradient centrifugation of the DNA. How many bands will you observe what will be their intensity?
Option C: c) Three with middle one more intense than upper and lower
Explanation: Explanation: In semi conservative replication initially the DNA was N15-N15.  After 1st round of replication both strands were N14-N15, making only a single band as they have same density. In the next round we will get N14N14, and  N14-N15 making two bands which are equally intense for having 1:1 concentration.

Question: 2. What will be the fate of a Seq A mutant E. Coli?
Option A: a) DNA replication will occur less frequently
Option B: b) Replication will be error prone
Explanation: Explanation: Seq A ( Seq standing for sequestering) blocks the newly produced DNA stand from Methylase. This plays an important role in Mis-Match repair. In its absence Mis-match repair will be non functional producing erroneous DNA.

Question: 3. At which end are the new DNA bases added?
Explanation: Explanation: DNA replication proceeds from 5Õ -> 3Õ direction with new bases being added to 3Õ-OH end. 5Õ-P is at the beginning of DNA Strand.

Question: 4. How many prokaryotic DNA polymerases have 5Õ->3Õ proofreading activity?
Explanation: Explanation: Only DNA polymerase I has 5Õ->3Õ proofreading activity. Other polymerases like pol II and III have 3Õ -> 5Õ proofreading activity. There are mainly 3 prokaryotic DNA polymerases.

Question: 5. Which is the most processive of prokaryotic DNA polymerases?
Explanation: Explanation: DNA pol III holoenzyme has a processivity of >500,000 which is highest among prokaryotic polymerases. Pol I,II and Klenow fragment has no beta clamp resulting in their lesser processivity.

Question: 7. In an experiment you take a DNA in vitro and attempt to replicate it. Which combination will you add to your DNA to get the maximum replication product?
Option A: a) Dna a, Dna b, HU, SSB, topoisomerase I, polymerase I
Option B: b) Dna a, Dna b, HU, SSB, polymerase III
Option C: c) Dna a, Dna b,  Dna c, HU ,SSB  polymerase I
Option D: d) Dna a, Dna b, Dna c, HU, SSB, polymerase III
Explanation: Explanation: DNA pol I has primase activity which is mandatory for starting DNA replication. As pol III lacks primase activity it will not be able to initiate replication. Also in vitro(specially in open DNA strand) topoisomerase doesnÕt have much role to play but Dna c is a must for replication as it loads the helicase.

Question: 8. In an experiment you use DNA pol  I Ð Klenow fragment. When all other requisites for replication are added, then what will be the effect on the newly replicated DNA? Consider leading strand only.
Option A: a) No difference from intact DNA pol I replication
Option C: c) Replication will be error prone
Option D: d) DNA produced will be shorter
Explanation: Explanation: Klenow fragment provides the 5Õ -> 3Õ exonuclease activity used to remove the primer. In its absence the primer remains and hence DNA produced is shorter (i.e. original length-length of primer).

Question: 9. You take a circular ssDNA and to it you attach a small labeled complimentary fragment. You add different reagents and try to get free labeled probe. Which of this reagent will give you your desired result?
Explanation: Explanation: Dna b has helicase activity which can separate two complementary DNA strands, this will break the link between labeled fragment and circular DNA rendering it free. Dna G mainly has primase activity while Dna a and Dna c are required for replication initiation which donÕt give the desired result.

Question: 10. Which of this subunit is not a part of core DNA polymerase?
Explanation: Explanation: Beta is the clamp which helps to provide polymerase with higher processivity, however even in its absence DNA replication will take place although processivity of polymerase would be slow. Alpha is the centre for polymerase activity and it along with theta and eta forms the core polymerase.

Question: 11. Rolling circle mode of replication is ________
Explanation: Explanation: One cycle of replication results in an inner parent circular strand and outer daughter circular strand making the process semi-conservative. It would have been conservative if resultant parent and daughter strand would be on different molecules and dispersed if both strands would have some part of parent and daughter.

Question: 12. What constitutes Primosome?
Option A: a) Dna a, Dna b, Dna c, Dna G
Explanation: Explanation: Dna b, the helicase, and Dna G, the primase, constitutes the primosome necessary for initiation. Dna a mainly generates a strain allowing Dna c to load the helicase Dna b.

Question: 13. If we mutate the DNA ligase and observe the length of the replicated strands in different time slots after replication initiation, what will we observe?
Option A: a) The DNA will gradually increase in length till it is fully replicated
Option B: b) Small fragments of DNA will be obtained increasing in number with time
Option C: c) Mixture of small and long Fragments of definite length from the start whose concentration simply increases with time
Option D: d) At first small fragment, then two separate bands showing long fragment with increasing length and short fragments of definite length.
Explanation: Explanation: The small fragments are the Okazaki fragments of lagging strand while the longer is the leading stand DNA. While leading strand grows in length the Okazaki fragments in absence of ligation to each other results in small fragments of definite length.

Question: 14. Acyclovir is a drug used to treat viral infection by impairing its replication. Why will it not effect bacterial replication as well?
Option A: a) Bacteria under viral attack donÕt replicate
Option B: b) Viral polymerase binds to it and thus canÕt perform its function
Option C: c) Virus uses it in a polymerization
Explanation: Explanation: Acyclovir is a GMP analogue that cellular mechanism activates to GTP analogue, which the virus uses as a substrate while polymerizing. However, as it lacks 3Õ-OH it terminates the replication process. Thus, cellular processes activate this drug, yet its specificity to viral polymerase protects the cell.

Question: 15. DNA replication in the two strands proceed in opposite direction as they are aligned oppositely with respect to 3Õ and 5Õ ends
Option C: In this context which of the following is true.
Option D: a) The two arms of the DNA Pol are exactly same with same orientation
Explanation: Explanation: The two arms have the core subunits and beta clamp in the same orientation. The DNA strand loops through the lagging strand synthesizing arm to allow polymerization in the same direction (say right to left). However, both arms would polymerize from 5Õ->3Õ direction only.

Question: 1. In case of eukaryotes replication initiates at ________
Explanation: Explanation: Replication begins at ARS Ð Autonomous Replicating Sequences. While TATA and CpG islets are characteristics of promoter elements which controls transcription. Translation initiates at AUG codon.

Question: 2. Here are names of some factors necessary for prokaryotic replication. Which of these or their homologue is unnecessary for eukaryotes?
Explanation: Explanation: DNA G (gyrase) is not needed for eukaryotes. While Dna b homologue MCM, Beta clamp homologue PCNA and SSB homologue RPA are necessary.

Question: 3. You wanted to find out the importance of the DNA polymerases. So, you mutated the polymerases one by one and checked for survival. In which of these mutant cases will you see least survival rate?
Explanation: Explanation: Alpha has primase activity. Without a primer DNA synthesis canÕt initiate thus Alpha polymerase is indispensible. While the beta is mainly needed for repair mechanisms it doesnÕt make much difference. However, delta and eta are main polymerases for eukaryotes and their mutation will have major effects as well.

Question: 4. You design a circular ssDNA with a labeled RNA primer (alpha-P32 labeling). You add polymerase epsilon and required enzymes for replication to the fragment. What will you expect to see on autoradiography after gel electrophoresis?
Option A: a) Single labeled band with some labeling at the bottom region
Option B: b) Two labeled band one much lower than the other with labeling at the bottom region
Option C: c) No band but labeling at the bottom
Option D: d) Two labeled band one much lower than the other with no labeling at the bottom
Explanation: Explanation: Alpha-P32 incorporated the label in the entire RNA primer fragment. As polymerization will take place the 5Õ->3Õ exonuclease activity of pol eta will produce labeled oligomers of that RNA. One band will correspond to unreplicated DNA, the lower one to oligomer. No labeled monomer is produced.

Question: 5. You design a plasmid with a gene for Histidine synthesis and a fragment containing ARS. You introduce it yeast culture and try to grow then in Histidine deficit media. What will be your observation?
Option C: c) Rapid growth with many colonies
Option D: d) Normal growth with countable colonies
Explanation: Explanation: ARS promotes replication of the yeast. Even if the plasmid was initially taken up by few cells due to rapid replication brought about by ARS the number of colony massively increases. If the same experiment was done with any random stretch of DNA none or few colonies would be seen.

Question: 6. Deletion of which domain of ARS would give the least replication rate in eukaryotes?
Explanation: Explanation: The 11bp ÔA domainÕ is the primary functional area of the ARS. Mutation in this domain gives 0% functionality of ORC so lease replication. Other mutations also reduce replication rate but not to such extent.

Question: 7. Which subunit in MCM is not phosphorylated in MCM after initiation is triggered?
Explanation: Explanation: MCM has 6 subunits numbered from 2 to 7. After initiation of replication is triggered all subunits other than 2 are phosphorylated.

Question: 8. You are given a DNA fragment with a CBD lesion. Which polymerase(s) will you use to replicate this fragment without taking care of the error?
Explanation: Explanation: Eta introduces two random base against the lesion say AA or TT.  However, it is very error prone and requires zeta to carry out the remaining replication. Kappa and theta also participate in repair but by other ways.

Question: 9. We know that Beta clamp in bacteria has two subunits and takes the shape of a ring. Which of this will be characteristic of PCNA which is a beta clamp homologue for eukaryotes?
Option C: c) Four subunits forming figure 8 like structure
Option D: d) Four subunits forming a larger ring
Explanation: Explanation: PCNA has three subunits but its structure is similar (ring) like two subunit beta clamp. Larger ring formation would be unreasonable as the basic structure of DNA is exactly the same for both prokaryotes and eukaryotes.

Question: 10. What is the function of RFC in eukaryotic replication?
Explanation: Explanation: RFC or Replication Factor C is the eukaryotic homologue of clamp loader. It loads the PCNA clamp. Eukaryotic replication primer is formed by alpha polymerase while RPA acts as SSB.

Question: 1.  Cyclin-CDK complex (here considering S cyclin) when active is responsible for phosphorylating several proteins and this often marks then for destruction by ubiquitination. What would be its effect on Cdt activity?
Explanation: Explanation: Cdt a protein necessary for initiation of replication is sequestered by geminin. S-cyclin-CDK phosphorylates and marks geminin for ubiquitination which makes Cdt free to express its activity. However, it has no effect on Cdt concentration or synthesis.

Question: 2. Which of these would you use as a competitive inhibitor for Cdt?
Explanation: Explanation: MCM 10 replaces Cdt from pre-replication complex triggering the phosphorylation in the next step. Thus, it must have a similar structure to Cdt and can act as a competitive inhibitor. While there is no MCM 1, MCM 2-7 form a member helicase.

Question: 3. What is the fate of phosphorylated Cdc 6?
Option A: a) It is transported outside nucleus
Option D: d) It forms a complex with Cdt
Explanation: Explanation: Cdc 6 after triggering initiation dissociates from ORC and is phosphorylated to prevent re-initiation. It undergoes ubiquitination and destruction while MCM is phosphorylated and transported outside the nucleus. It ensures that Cdc 6 and MCM remain inactive and canÕt re-initiate replication.

Question: 4.  Pre-replication complex is necessary to initiate replication. It assembles in______________
Explanation: Explanation: Pre-replication complex assembles on ORC in G1 phase. It is triggered in S phase when no new Pre-RC assembly takes place. Even during early Anaphase and late Anaphase this complex assembly is prevented.

Question: 5. Which Cyclin-CDK complex will you find most active in M phase?
Explanation: Explanation: Cyclin B Ð CDK 1 is corresponding to the yeast M-Cyclin-CDK complex which is active during M phase and leads to Anaphase. Cyclin D is G1-S cyclin, Cyclin A is S cyclin and Cyclin E is G1 cyclin respectively.

Question: 6.  What is the DNA composition of ARS?
Explanation: Explanation: A-T bases bound by 2 hydrogen bonds unlike G and C, which are bound by 3 hydrogen bonds. In such region DNA strand separation is easier as compared to G-C rich regions. Hence, ARS which requires DNA melting to initiate replication is A-T rich.

Question: 7. In an experiment, you are working on mitochondrial chromosomes. Which polymerase will ensure accurate replication?
Explanation: Explanation: Pol gamma is the mitochondrial DNA polymerase, while pol beta is mainly necessary for repair. Pol iota associates with translesion DNA synthesis. Pol delta is the primary nuclear DNA polymerase.

Question: 8. To your cultured cell lines, you add growth factors like cytokines which act through MAPK cascade pathway. Which transition will it trigger?
Explanation: Explanation: One of the primary checkpoints to overcome incase of proliferation is G1 -> S check point. MAPK cascade leads to transcription of genes required to increase the CDK activity that leads to this transition. Once S phase is completed the cell must undergo mitosis although there is another checkpoint before Anaphase.

Question: 1. Which protein mentioned below can reverse central dogma?
Explanation: Explanation: Reverse transcriptase helps in cDNA synthesis from RNA, which is opposite to the central dogma, where RNA is synthesized from DNA. Ribosome and RNA polymerases obey central dogma, while Restriction Endonuclease is unrelated as it simply cleaves DNA at a specific site.

Question: 2. The catalytic activity resides in which subunit of RNA polymerase?
Explanation: Explanation: __ and _ subunits are mainly associated with the transcription start site where __ subunit mainly confers the catalytic activity. The sigma subunit provides specificity while alpha subunit interacts with regulatory proteins.

Question: 3. What is the direction in which the transcript produced by RNA polymerase grows?
Explanation: Explanation: In the process of RNA synthesis there is a short phase of hybrid DNA-RNA formation. This is possible only when two strands are oppositely oriented. As 3Õ-OH is necessary for adding new nucleotides, RNA is synthesized from 5Õ->3Õ direction, so the template must be 3Õ->5Õ oriented.

Question: 4. In an experiment you use RNA polymerase without its sigma factor for transcription. What will be the result that you observe?
Explanation: Explanation: Sigma subunit is responsible for recognizing the transcription start site. In its absence the RNA pol will transcribe at non-specific random sites. Sigma plays no role in the rate of transcription so there is no chance in transcription rate in its absence.

Question: 5. In an experiment you mutate the consensus sequence at the -10 box. You observe the rate of transcription reduces. Now you make complementary mutation to the sigma factor. What will you observe?
Option A: a) Further decrease in transcription rate
Option D: d) Increase in rate of random transcription
Explanation: Explanation: Complementary mutation in sigma factor helps to restore its -10 box recognition capacity which restores normal transcription rate. However, to improve the rate further both the -10 and -35 box sequences should be made more like the consensus.

Question: 6. You wanted to isolate active RNA polymerase (with a part of the transcript associated with it ) from cellular mix. For this, you perform an immunoprecipitation with anti sigma antibody. Then you check the precipitate. What will you observe?
Option D: d) DNA with associated RNA polymerase and a transcript
Explanation: Explanation: Sigma factor dissociates after initiation so anti sigma antibody will only pull down RNA polymerase prior to promoter clearance. Thus, the polymerases so obtained have no transcript associated.

Question: 7. Which part of sigma factor associates with -10box?
Explanation: Explanation: the 2.4 i.e. (4th part of 2nd subunit) associates with the -10box in promoter. While 4.2 associates with -35box of the promoter. 1.2 sub unit doesnÕt associate with DNA; and there is no 4.4 unit in sigma factor.

Question: 8. You want to find out which of the consequent gene X or Y is being transcribed. For this you do a hybridization competition analysis and plot the radioactivity curve with increasing concentration of the competitor unlabelled mRNA. If the transcribed gene was X, which observation fits your result?
Option A: a) The radioactivity of y decreases while that of x remains the same
Option B: b) The radioactivity of x decreases while that of y remains the same
Option C: c) The radioactivity of x and y decreases
Option D: d) The radioactivity of y decreases while x increases
Explanation: Explanation: As the unlabelled mRNA against X will compete with the labeled one for hybridization the intensity of radioactivity will gradually decrease with increased concentration. But as it will not bind to Y gene the Y labeled mRNA faces no competition and its intensity remains same.

Question: 9. Which of these is the 1st event to take place during transcription initiation?
Option A: a) Formation of a closed initiation complex
Option B: b) Formation of open initiation complex
Explanation: Explanation: When the RNA pol is attached to DNA strands that have still not melted the complex so formed is called open initiation complex. When the DNA melts it is known as open initiation complex. This follows the formation of abortive transcript and promoter clearance.

Question: 10. The catalytic unit of RNA polymerases when placed properly during initiation is just over _________
Explanation: Explanation: The catalytic subunit is exactly over the first nucleotide of mRNA which is at +1 site. -1 signifies one site upstream to initiation while there is no 0 site. -10 box is recognized by sigma factor.

Question: 11. In an experiment you mutate the C terminal domain of alpha subunit of the RNA polymerase. What will you expect to see?
Option B: b) Transcription is at random sites
Explanation: Explanation: The C terminal domain of the alpha subunit is responsible for binding to the UP elements of the promoter. Such binding helps to enhance transcription so in absence of the binding transcription will be slower. However, still transcription will occur due to the presence of core promoter.

Question: 13. In an experiment you add increasing amount of sigma factor to a mixture of DNA fragment and core polymerase in vitro. You also add [14C]ATP and  [_-32P]ATP in the mixture and check the rate of incorporation. Results show that the incorporation of both of this labels increase on adding more sigma factor. What will you conclude from your observation?
Option A: a) Sigma confers specificity and increases transcription rate
Option B: b) Sigma increases initiation and elongation rate
Option C: c) Sigma increases initiation of transcription rate
Explanation: Explanation: [_-32P]ATP incorporation marks more initiation while [14C]ATP incorporation indicates elongation. As on adding sigma factor both incorporations seems to increase, sigma must increase both initiation and elongation rate.

Question: 14. In an experiment, you wanted to see which mutation will have worse effect on transcription. In the 1st set you deleted 94 amino acids from the C-terminus and in the 2nd set you replace the 265th C-terminal arginine to cystine. Which in your opinion will have the worst effect?
Option C: c) Both will have similar negative effect
Option D: d) No visible effect on rate of transcription
Explanation: Explanation: This is because the 265th arginine is most important for recognition of the up element. Thus, its deletion alone can have a similar negative effect on transcription to the deletion of 94 amino acids from C terminal end.

Question: 15. Which cation is placed in the catalytic subunit of RNA polymerase?
Explanation: Explanation: Magnesium ion is mandatory for the catalytic action as it shields the negative charge of the phosphate groups of rNTPs and also promotes the nucleophilic attack by the 3Õ-OH group. Manganese, zinc and iron are part of other biologically important enzymes.

Question: 1. While studying the transcripts in vitro you observe that other than the longer transcripts there are some short stretches of RNA oligomer produced as well. You repeat the experiment several times but these oligomers seem to persist. What is the possible explanation?
Option B: b) They are the un-ligated oligomers of lagging strand
Explanation: Explanation: These short oligomers are abortive transcripts produced by the RNA polymerase before it leaves the promoter. There is no lagging strand in RNA and since the experiment is repeated several times with caution the other justifications are rules out.

Question: 2. Capping of RNA is necessary as_______
Option A: a) It helps us distinguish 5Õ from 3Õ end
Option B: b) It has a rolling action and condenses the transcript as it is produced
Option C: c) To protect the transcript from exonuclease
Option D: d) To prevent the transcript from sticking to DNA
Explanation: Explanation: There are several free exonuclease in the nucleus and the 5Õ cap protects the mRNA from them. In its absence, valuable information will be lost from the transcript and abnormal proteins would result after translation. RNA normally font stick to DNA and absence of ATPase activity rules out 2nd option.

Question: 3. What is the 1st nucleotide of a completely synthesized transcript?
Explanation: Explanation: The 5Õ cap can be considered as the 1st nucleotide of the complete transcript. And as it is ppGpp the nucleotide is Guanine or G.

Question: 4. Processivity of RNA polymerase is ________
Explanation: Explanation: RNA polymerase is highly processive as when the sigma subunit dissociates the DNA binding arm of RNA polymerase clamps shut around the DNA prevents it from falling off. DNA polymerase I on the other hand has low processivity.

Question: 5. Which antibiotic inhibits transcription elongation?
Explanation: Explanation: Streptolydigin prevents elongation while Rifampicin prevents initiation. Penicillin and Tetracyclin act on the ribosome and not on RNA polymerase although even they ultimately inhibit protein synthesis.

Question: 6. You design a reconstructive RNA polymerase where you take the beta and alpha subunit from a rifampicin resistant strain and beta prime and sigma subunit from rifampicin sensitive strain. You check the rate of transcription by this RNA polymerase after the addition of the antibiotic. What will be your observation?
Explanation: Explanation: The beta subunit of the RNA polymerase is mainly sensitive to Rifampicin. Thus the re-constructed RNA pol is overall Rifampicin resistant and transcription rate will be normal.

Question: 7. You add labeled Uridine analogue to the mixture of DNA and RNA pol in vitro. What are you trying to determine?
Option A: a) Catalytic subunit of RNA pol
Option C: c) Presence of DNA Ð RNA hybrid
Option D: d) Length of DNA already transcribed
Explanation: Explanation: The Uridine analogue can base pair with the RNA pol enzyme when there is a presence of a complementary strand (here DNA). Thus, its incorporation and cross linking will confirm the presence of RNA-DNA hybrid. We use labeled NTP to detect the other processes mentioned.

Question: 8. Which of these is not a part of RNA polymerase elongation machinery?
Explanation: Explanation: As the RNA is synthesized there is an RNA exit channel but there is no need of RNA entry channel. Clamp and flap on the other hand help to stabilize the polymerase structure.

Question: 9. Melting of DNA would lead to _________________
Explanation: Explanation: Melting is the separation of the two strands of DNA which causes an increase in the amount of UV rays absorbed by the DNA. This is known as Hyperchromic shift. It has no effect on florescence of DNA.

Question: 10. In a stretch of DNA being transcribed, the region forward to the Elongation is __________
Explanation: Explanation: The region forward to the RNA polymerase elongation machinery is positively supercoiled due to the strain. If the gyrase doesnÕt release this strain the polymerizing machinery will stall. Such regions canÕt be uncoiled or folded.

Question: 1.  What form of helix would you expect to see in double stranded RNA?
Explanation: Explanation: Double stranded RNA generally forms A form helix while double stranded DNA forms B form helix. The other forms also occur in DNA under special conditions.

Question: 2. A ssRNA shows inverted tandem repeat. What would be its secondary structure?
Explanation: Explanation: A tandem repeat has some bases between the palindrome regions resulting in the formation of the loop. The remaining complementary sequences of the palindrome forms the stem. In case of dsRNA similar sequence would form a crucifix while absence of intersecting sequence will form hairpin.

Question: 3. To study the functioning of intrinsic terminator you increase the number of G-C base pairs in the stem and decrease the U bases from the tail region. What would be its effect on termination?
Option D: d) The RNA polymerase will stall at the terminator
Explanation: Explanation:  The increase in number of G-C base pairs in the stem region stabilizes the stem, and decreasing in number of U in the tail destabilizes it. These two have a compensating effect on terminator efficiency.

Question: 4. Which of these interactions is the weakest?
Explanation: Explanation: The interaction between A and T or U base is through 2 hydrogen bonds only. So this is weaker than G-C which mediates by 3 hydrogen bonds. Further RNA DNA interactions are weaker making rU-dA the weakest of interaction which is used in termination of transcription.

Question: 5. You modify your gene DNA sequence by introducing an attenuator within the transcribed region. You isolate the labeled gene product and perform SDS PAGE. You observe two bands one higher and another slightly lower. Which of this band corresponds to properly modified sequence?
Option C: c) Both the bands as they show differently folded protein
Option D: d) This is an experimental artifact
Explanation: Explanation: An attenuator will lead to premature transcription termination. This will result in a truncated protein that will migrate faster in the gel and form the lower band. Protein folding doesnÕt affect its migration in SDS page.

Question: 6. Rho protein, that is necessary for transcription termination, is a ________
Explanation: Explanation: Rho is a 46KDa hexameric protein with 6 identical subunits. Thus, it is a holohexamer. A four subunit protein with all identical subunit would be a holotetramer, not identical subunit would be heterotetramer respectively.

Question: 7. Rho shows base preference although it doesnÕt have any concensus cis binding sequence. Which region will be expected to bind Rho better?
Option A: a) G and C rich region
Option B: b) A and T rich region
Option C: c) Region rich in C and poor in G
Option D: d) Region rich in A and poor in T
Explanation: Explanation: Rho binds best to regions having high C content as much as 41% and low G content as much as 14%. As in RNA there is no compulsory base pairing the amount of G is not necessary equal to the amount of c.

Question: 8. Rho dependent termination mechanism doesnÕt reguire____________
Explanation: Explanation: Sigma factor plays no role in termination, rather it dissociates long before the RNA pol terminates. Rho however requires ATP for its rolling function and the stem loop structure formation. This stem loop structure is strengthened by G-C rich regions in the stem.

Question: 9.  When Rho catches up with RNA polymerase it _______
Explanation: Explanation: Rho protein helps in termination of transcription. It binds to the growing transcript rolls up and catches up with the polymerase when the loop starts to form. This dissociates the complex from the DNA leading to the formation of free Rho, DNA, RNA transcript and polymerase.

Question: 10. You can see non-cannonical base pairing in________
Explanation: Explanation: Along with canonical base pairing with the normal base pairs according to Watson-Crick rules, dsRNA also forms non-cannonical base pairs. However, dsDNA canÕt do so. ssRNA and ssDNA are called so because they are single stranded so there is no base pairing at all.

Question: 12. Which of these proteins help to backtrack the RNA?
Explanation: Explanation: When the RNA polymerase encounters a bulky lesion the NER protein CSA heps the RNA to backtrack giving the NER mechanism a clearance of 100bp to act. XPC and TFIIH are also needed in NER but have different function. DNA G is a primase needed in prokaryotic replication.

Question: 1.  If you study T4 bacteriophage transcription with holoenzyme which genes will you expect to be transcribed?
Explanation: Explanation: Sigma factor in holoenzyme ensures transcription of immediate early gene first soon after viral infection. This is followed by delayed and late gene transcription. Core  Enzyme shows no such specificity.

Question: 2. You transcribe a gene and obtain mRNA. To detect which strand is transcribed you replicate each strand in vitro and use the newly synthesized strand for hybridization with mRNA. If mRNA hybridize with the newly replicated strand from 1st strand then the gene transcribed was in ________
Option C: c) Same copy in both strands
Explanation: Explanation: mRNA produced from 1st strand and DNA produced by replicating 1st strand should have the same sequence and they will not hybridize. However, if the gene is transcribed from 2nd strand then this result is possible. RNA pol only transcribes one strand at a time so dispersed and both being transcribed are not possible.

Question: 3. When sigma subunit dissociates from the RNA polymerase what happens to the DNA binding clamp of the core?
Option C: c) It enters a semi open stage
Option D: d) It is phophorylated and ubiquitination occurs
Explanation: Explanation: In the absence of the sigma subunit initially the RNA Pol clamp is closed. Sigma makes a window of open clamp conformation when RNA pol loads on the DNA. When sigma dissociates the clamp closes again around the DNA preventing the pol to fall off.

Question: 4. In an experiment you wrongly added Rifampicin antibiotic to Rifampicin sensitive bacteria. You try to correct your mistake by adding more core subunits (resistant to Rifampicin) to your mixture. What would you expect to see?
Option B: b) Transcription will restart but it will be non-specific as you added core enzyme
Option C: c) Impaired transcription with more abortive transcripts
Explanation: Explanation: The sigma factor is not affected by Rifampicin and it is dissociable. The sigma already present in mixture will add to the Rifampicin resistant core and restore normal transcription of specific genes. No increased abortive transcription will be seen.

Question: 5. Which is the primary sigma factor in Bacillus subtilis?
Explanation: Explanation: _43 is the normally active sigma factor for Bacillus subtilis while _70 is the normally active sigma factor for E. coli. _32 is expressed under stressed conditions like heat shock when it competes with _70 for RNA pol core.

Question: 6. What is the function of 1st subunit of sigma factor in _70 and _43?
Option A: a) It helps to bind sigma to DNA
Option B: b) It helps to bind sigma to core beta subunit
Option C: c) It helps to bind sigma to core alpha subunit
Option D: d) It prevents sigma to bind to DNA
Explanation: Explanation: The 1st region forms a flap like structure that blocks the DNA binding sites. This helps to prevent unbound sigma to bind to DNA. That will only block the DNA binding site and lead to no transcription in absence of RNA pol.

Question: 7. Loosening the binding between polymerase and non-specific site is important to confer higher specificity. In Bacillus subtilis what is responsible for this action?
Explanation: Explanation: While _70 in E. coli has an extra 245 amino acid that helps it to loosen the polymerase from non-specific site, _43 in Bacillus subtilis lacks it. Thus, it needs another subunit of core polymerase- delta subunit to perform this function.

Question: 8. We know that region 2.4 of sigma factor binds DNA at -10box. What is the function of 2.1?
Option A: a) It is a flexible loop with no known function
Option D: d) It binds region 4.1 to give sigma its specific structure and function
Explanation: Explanation: Region 2.1 helps to bind the sigma factor to the RNA polymerase. The binding is not absolute as this factor is dissociable. -35box on the other hand is recognized by region 4.2.

Question: 9. Which DNA binding domain is seen in region 4.2 of sigma factor?
Explanation: Explanation: Region 4.2 of sigma subunit has a helix turn helix motif that helps it to bind to the major groove of DNA. The similar motif has been seen in region 3 as well. Zinc fingers and leucine zipper are examples of other DNA binding motif.

Question: 10. Which sigma factor is bound to Rse A?
Explanation: Explanation: Rse A binds _E and prevents it from activating transcription. Under extreme conditions this binding is broken by cleavage of c terminal cytosolic tail of transmambrane Rse A, thus releasing _E for transcribing necessary genes.

Question: 11. You artificially increase the level of _32 in an E. coli culture. What will you expect to see?
Option A: a) rpo H transcription permanently inhibited
Option B: b) cdc transcription constitutively turned on
Explanation: Explanation: _32 is necessary for transcribing genes like rpo H that helps in surviving heat shock while it doesnÕt act on cdc6 that has a role in replication. As _32 is unstable it temporarily turns on rho H till the concentration ratio of _32 and _70 returns to normal.

Question: 12. If a bacteria is facing lack of carbon sources in the media, which sigma factor concentration is expected to increase?
Explanation: Explanation: Sigma S is synthesized when the cell is under stressed conditions as in stationary phase. It transcribes rpo S gene which helps to overcome carbon starvation in stationary phase. Sigma E works in extreme conditions of shock, while sigma 70 and 43 work in normal conditions.

Question: 1.  You want your bacterial culture to grow well so you made an enriched media with all forms of carbohydrates. Which of this carbohydrate should you restore first if you want the culture to keep growing at the same rate?
Explanation: Explanation: Prokaryotes first use all the glucose in the media to derive energy. Only when they sense a low glucose level they search alternative energy sources like lactose, fructose or galactose.

Question: 2. In a mero-diploid you have one I- and one I+ Repressor gene in the two lac operons. I+ is wild type while I- is a mutant which produces a repressor that doesnÕt bind. What would be the functionality of the diploid?
Option C: c) May or may not function
Explanation: Explanation: The set of gene product produced from the wild type I+ loci will be sufficient to induce repression in both the operons. Thus, the system will not be impaired or non-functional.

Question: 3. Which of these Lac operon mero- diploid will be constitutively turned on? Considering the terms has their usual meaning.
Option B: b) I+ + P + OC + Z+ + Y+ + A+ / I+ + P+ O+ + Z+ + Y+ + A+
Option C: c) Is + P + O+ + Z+ + Y+ + A+ / I+ + P+ O+ + Z+ + Y+ + A+
Option D: d) I+ + P + O+ + Z+ + Y+ + A+ / IÐ + P+ O+ + Z+ + Y+ + A+
Explanation: Explanation: OC is an operon that canÕt bind to the repressor. Consecutively it is always turned on. IS produces a repressor which binds tightly to operon and never lets it turn on- This is the case of constitutively turning off.

Question: 4. Which of these combinations will result is am operon that can never produce beta galactosidse?
Option A: a) IÐ + P + O+ + Z+ + Y+ + A+ / I+ + P+ O+ + Z+ + Y+ + A+
Option B: b) I+ + P + OC + ZÐ + Y+ + A+ / I+ + P+ O+ + ZÐ + Y+ + A+
Option C: c) Is + P + OC + Z+ + Y+ + A+ / I+ + P+ OC + Z+ + Y+ + A+
Option D: d) I-d + P + O+ + Z+ + Y+ + A+ / IÐ + P+ O+ + Z+ + Y+ + A+
Explanation: Explanation: This is because although this operon is constitutively turned on, yet it has a mutated lac Z gene which produces beta galactosidase. This mutation exists in both of the loci so it canÕt produce this enzyme even if the operon is on.

Question: 5. Which of the Ars operon regulation site is actually preventing RNA polymerase from binding and producing the Ara genes BAD?
Explanation: Explanation: Although O2 is much farther from the ara promoter P yet it can regulate P as it loops out and reaches the site. On the other hand O1 however being closer doesnÕt control the promoter of BAD genes.

Question: 6. Which of these Ara genes is a mode of feedback autoregulation?
Explanation: Explanation: As ara C level rises it itself binds beside its promoter preventing the RNA polymerase to bind to the same there by having a negative feedback control. Ara BAD promoter lacks this type of control and is regulate din different way.

Question: 7. In which of this condition is Ara operon functional?
Option A: a) When repressor binds to O2 and I1
Option B: b) When repressor binds to O1 and I2
Option C: c) When repressor binds to I2 and I1
Option D: d) When repressor binds to O2 and Pc
Explanation: Explanation: When repressor binds to I1 and I2 then RNA polymerase faces no hindrance in binding to the promoter and the genes are turned on. On the other hand when induces the repressor bind to O2 and I1 which leads to the looping out and turning off.

Question: 8. Which of the Ara promoter regulation is controlled by binding of repressors on the O1 regulating unit?
Explanation: Explanation: When Ara C is produced in excess it bind to O1 and represses the promoter PC. This is true as o1 lies closer to PC. However the other promoter PBAD has a regulating unit O2 that acts from a distance by looping out.

Question: 1.  Which of these operons is anabolic?
Explanation: Explanation: Trp operon is anabolic as it codes for enzymes that help in the synthesis of the amino acid tryptophan. On the other hand Ara and Lac operons are catabolic as they help in breaking down the respective sugar.

Question: 2. Which of these systems give the best mode for turning trp operon off?
Option C: c) Repressor with a downstream poly A tail
Explanation: Explanation:  A repressor provides 70 fold lowering of expression while an attenuator provided an additional 10 fold lowering of expression. Together they have a net effect of 700 fold repression over the trp operon.

Question: 3. A Lac repressor is a tetramer repressed when bound to the inducer. The trp repressor is a ____________________
Option A: a) Dimer inactivated when bound to the inducer
Option B: b) Dimer activated on inducer binding
Option C: c) Tetramer inactivated on inducer binding
Option D: d) Tetramer activated on inducer binding
Explanation: Explanation: A trp repressor is a dimer which canÕt bind to the cis element unless it is bound to the inducer tryptophan. Only then it undergoes conformational change such that it then binds to the operator.

Question: 4. Which of these properties do not agree with trp operon attenuator?
Option A: a) It brings about repression of trp operon
Option B: b) It consists of one stem loop system
Option C: c) It has two codons for tryptophan in sequence
Option D: d) Ribosome stalls at the attenuator
Explanation: Explanation: Attenuator doesÕt just contain one loop but it can form two in presence of tryptophan and an alternate one in absence of the same for B. subtilis and one terminator and another anti-terminator loops for E. Coli. The other facts about trp operon are absolutely correct.

Question: 5. Which segments of the attenuator together form the repression loop?
Explanation: Explanation: In the absence of tryptophan when the RNA polymerase stalls at segment 1 of the attenuator it hinders the formation of loop 1-2. The alternate loop so formed is loop 2-3 which is the attenuation loop.

Question: 6. We know that lactose has a positive impact on the activity of the lac operon. TryptophanÕs presence has a ________________
Explanation: Explanation: Trp binding to the TRAP makes a trp-TRAP complex which binds to the RNA and stabilizes the terminator loop. Hence, TryptophanÕs presence has a negative feedback effect.

Question: 7. If in an experiment you mutate the two trp codons in the attenuator to ala codon what will be the impact on repression?
Option C: c) No repression so the gene would be constitutively turned on
Explanation: Explanation: The basis of attenuation at the attenuator is the presence of two trp operon which stalls the RNA polymerase when trp is deficient. Mutating the trp to ala eliminates the attenuatorÕs mode of repression. However, there is still an intrinsic mode of repression by binding of a repressor, which is still active.

Question: 8. Which of these items have a positive impact on PEDCBA transcription?
Explanation: Explanation: Anti- trp is an auto-regulating molecule that is sensitive to different levels of tryptophan. When tryptophan conc. is high enough to form trp-TRAP complex yet lower than necessary it binds to the Trp-TRAP complex thus preventing repression.

Question: 9. When uncharged tRNA concentration is low what will you expect as the activity of tryptophan operon?
Explanation: Explanation: When uncharged tRNA concentration is low this is because of lack of trp. This inactivates anti-trap gene and thus there is no attenuation at all in trp gene. Thus activity is high.

Question: 10. How many stem loop structures play important role in complete system of tryptophan gene regulation?
Explanation: Explanation: 3 stem loop for the attenuation and termination in trp gene itself and another 3 for attenuation and termination of anti-trp gene. Overall there are 6 stem loop structures which regulate the entire functioning.

Question: 11. Which of this mode of trp regulation is not possible in eukaryotes?
Explanation: Explanation: Attenuation of trp is based on ribosomal stalling at two trp codons which leads to the formation of attenuation loop. This is only possible for co-transcriptional translation which is absent in eukaryotes.

Question: 12. In which microorganism will you find attenuation by alternate loop formation due to ribosomal stalling?
Explanation: Explanation: This is a mechanism found in Bacillus subtilis; where other microorganisms like E. coli have a different mechanism. E. coli has the antiÐTRAP trp-TRAP mechanism.

Question: 13. Which operon behaves similar to Bacillus subtilis trp operon in terms of attenuation?
Explanation: Explanation: His operon, similar to B. subtilis trp operon, has a streach of 6 His codons in its attenuator which stalls the ribosome and helps in attenuation.

Question: 1.  Prokaryotes have 1 RNA polymerase. How many RNA polymerases are there in eukaryotes?
Explanation: Explanation: Eukaryotes have three RNA polymerases specialized in different types of RNA transcription. While RNA pol I mainly deals with rRNA, RNA pol II with mRNA and RNA pol III deals with tRNA and 5S rRNA.

Question: 2. You isolate the nucleolus from the nucleus and performed a density gradient centrifugation with the extract. Then you check the different for the RNA polymerase activity of the different segment. Which RNA polymerase would you expect to find in abundance?
Explanation: Explanation:  Nucleolus is the centre for rRNA production. As RNA pol I is mainly concerned with rRNA transcription we will expect to find this in abundance. Cytosolic extract on the other hand will be abundant in RNA pol II and III.

Question: 3. Which RNA polymerase can bind CBP?
Explanation: Explanation: CBP or C terminal binding protein binds to the C terminal tail of heptad repeats when it is phosphorylated. As RNA pol II is the only polymerase with a C terminal tail, only RNA pol II will bind the hepad repeat.

Question: 4. What is the sequence of the heptad repeat of C terminal domain?
Explanation: Explanation: A heptad repeat sequence is YSPTSPS where there are 3 phosphoryable serine residues at position 3, 5 and 7.

Question: 5. You designed an antibody against phosphorylated CTD of RNA polymerase II. Then you use a DNA fragment with lac operon and try to immunoprecipitate the RNA pol II. What will be the expected result?
Option A: a) Moderate concentration of RNA pol II will precipitate
Option B: b) RNA pol II that precipitated will be contaminated with pol III
Option C: c) High amount of RNA pol II will precipitate
Option D: d) No RNA pol II will precipitate
Explanation: Explanation: Lac operon is a prokaryotic gene not recognized by eukaryotic RNA polymerase. Thus it will not be transcribing. Non-Transcribing RNA pol II doesnÕt have phosphorylated residue in CTD, so it canÕt be immunoprecipitated with the given antibody.

Question: 6. If you consider a transcribing RNA pol II with a transcript as small as 30 bases, which serine residue in its CTD will be phosphorylated?
Explanation: Explanation: when RNA transcript is only 30 bases long it is still within the initiation range. Then the 2nd serine residue is phosphorylared only.

Question: 7. Which factor phosphorylates the serine residues in RNA pol II CTD?
Explanation: Explanation: TFIIH phosphorylates the serine 2 of the heptad repeat that drives the RNA pol into initiation. The other factors mentioned are only part of pre-initiation complex and not of transcribing RNA pol.

Question: 8. In what sequence are the serine residues in RNA pol II phosphorylated?
Explanation: Explanation: The phosphorylation is at the 2nd serine residue with the help of the TFIIH, and then during elongation the phosphorylation is at the 5th serine residue. Between these two there is a short phase of phosphorylation at the 7th serine.

Question: 9. In an experiment you add growing concentration of the alpha amanitin. What will be the sequence in which RNA polymerases are affected if at all?
Option A: a) Pol I -> pol III , pol II unaffected
Option C: c) pol III->pol II -> pol I
Option D: d) pol II -> pol III , pol I unaffected
Explanation: Explanation: RNA polymerase II is inactivated by very small level of alpha amanitin as low as 1 microgram per ml while on the other hand pol III is affected at 10 micrograms per ml concentration. Polymerase I remain unaffected even at very high alpha amanitin concentration.

Question: 10. RPA 2 is one of the larger subunits of RNA polymerase in eukaryotes. It is homologous to the prokaryotic _____________
Explanation: Explanation: RPA 2 is homologous to the beta subunit while RPA 1 is homologous to the beta prime subunit which is the catalytic subunit.

Question: 11. How many of eukaryotic RNA polymerase subunits are common for all three polymerases?
Explanation: Explanation: The beta, beta prime, two alpha and one omega subunit homology to eukaryotic RNA polis common in all three RNA polymerases. These are RPA 1-5 respectively. The rest subunits are non-essential or dispensable.

Question: 13. In a Drosophila polytene chromosome just before molting you add green labelled antibody against unphosphhorylated RNA pol II CTD and red labelled antibody against phosphorylated RNA pol II CTD. These give fluorescence on adding the respective substrates. What will be the colour in gene 74 EF and 75 B?
Explanation: Explanation: The 74EF and 75B genes are highly transcribed during and before molting. Thus, there would be many RNA pol II with phosphorylated CTD there which will bind the red labelled antibody. Yellow colour is seen when red and green fluorescence mix.

Question: 1.  Which of this is a cis binding element?
Explanation: Explanation: TBP or TATA binding protein is the part of TFIID complex that recognizes and binds the TATA consensus sequence in the promoter (cis element) of eukaryotic genes. The remaining options are also related to eukaryotic transcription but they have protein-protein interactions.

Question: 2. You wanted to study the assembly of preinitiation complex in eukaryotes. This is by the means of protein-protein interaction. Which of these methods you canÕt absolutely put in use there?
Explanation: Explanation: While primer extension method can be used to locate the 5Õ end of the RNA this doesnÕt do any help in studying the assembly of pre initiation complex- basically as thatÕs upstream to even transcription start site. The remaining methods are however very useful.

Question: 3. For performing EMSA what type of gel should be used?
Explanation: Explanation: A denaturing SDS PAGE would break the interactions between the factors which is being studied. Thus, a non-denaturing SDS PAGE is used. A native page on the other hand would be less clear while zymography is unrelated.

Question: 4. While performing EMSA, in which situation will you see the band highest?
Option A: a) You add TFIID, TFIIA and polymerase
Option B: b) You add TFIID, TFIIB, TFIIF and polymerase
Option C: c) You add TFIID, TFIIA, TFIIF and polymerase
Option D: d) You add TFIIA, TFIIB, TFIIF and polymerase
Explanation: Explanation: TFIID is absolutely necessary for any nucleation to take place at all. The complex formed by this composition is almost functional as TFIIA is not playing that important role. However, TFIIB and TFIID absence hugely effects the formation of pre-IC.

Question: 5. Which of these is not true for TFIIH?
Option B: b) On initiation the RNA pol starts transcribing leaving TFIIH at pre-IC
Option D: d) It is needed in Double Strand Break (DSB) repair
Explanation: Explanation: TFIIH is necessary for phosphorylating RNA pol and triggering its initiation. It moves on with the RNA pol after initiation starts. It also acts as a helicase which is put to use during DSB repair.

Question: 6. A mediator helps to connect ___________
Explanation: Explanation: As enhancer elements work from a distance the connecting DNA is often looped and the enhancer connects to the RNA pol bound TAF through a mediator. A silencer may connect to TAF in a similar way.

Question: 7. Which factor stimulated phosphorylation of CTD of RNA polymerase II?
Explanation: Explanation: While TFIIH is actually performing the kinase action, TFIIE stimulates TFIIH to phosphorylate the CTD. TFIIA and TFIIF play no role in phosphorylation.

Question: 8. The absence of which factor will prevent TFIIH and TFIIE recruitment?
Explanation: Explanation: RNA polymerase bound TFIIF is necessary for recruiting TFIIH and TFIIE, two important transcription factors that trigger the initiation finally.

Question: 9. Which of this is untrue about TBP?
Option A: a) It is a part of TFIID
Option B: b) It makes a kink in the DNA
Explanation: Explanation: TBP specifically recognizes and binds to TATA consensus sequence which makes it sequence dependent. Its correct orientation is however determined by other factors like TFIIA and TFIIB. It makes an 80 kink in the DNA and is a part of TFIID.

Question: 10. While in vitro transcription your RNA pol is stalled at a position due to mistreatment. Which factor could you act to help the RNA pol overcome the stalled stage?
Explanation: Explanation: TFIIS is the transcription factor that helps to overcome the transcriptional stalling of RNA polymerases and also to help the polymerase to backtrack.

Question: 1.  Promoter proximal elements is positioned ________________
Option D: d) Just before the start site
Explanation: Explanation: The promoter proximal elements are a part of the core promoter. They occur downstream to the promoter start site. Enhancers on the other hand are much farther and outside the core promoter.

Question: 2. TATA box in eukaryotes would be present in _________________
Option C: c) Cytoskeletal genes like that for actin
Explanation: Explanation: The highly specialized genes are likely to have a TATA box within their promoter. On the other hand the rest genes have TATAless promoters.

Question: 3. TFIIB can bind to a promoter element in the core promoter of eukaryotes. This element is __________
Explanation: Explanation: BRE stands for TFIIB recognition site. It is here that the element can bind. On the other hand TFIID binds at the TATA box.

Question: 4. Which of these is not a promoter element?
Explanation: Explanation: The CCAAT box is a part of the upstream activating elements which is upstream to the promoter. It is recognized by CTF or CCAAT recognizing Transcription Factor. The remaining options are part of a core promoter.

Question: 5. Which would be an appropriate method to detect the core promoter regions in a eukaryotic gene?
Explanation: Explanation: In linker scanning method a small segment of the DNA is removed from promoter region and replaced with a random segment to see its effect on the transcription rate. Thus, as absence of promoter would lead to less transcription this method can be used to detect promoter elements.

Question: 7. Which of these class III promoter type resemble class II?
Explanation: Explanation: The Type III of class III promoter is a non-classical class III promoter which resembles type II. It has a TATA box, PSE and an upstream DSE. There is no 4th type of class III promoter and type I and II donÕt resemble class II.

Question: 8. If you make a chimeric factor with the DNA binding element of an activator and a functional domain of a repressor, how will this factor behave?
Option A: a) It will act like a repressor
Option B: b) It will act like an activator
Option C: c) It will not be able to bind the DNA so although it binds via the repressing domain it wonÕt cause repression
Option D: d) Repression domain will be non-functional
Explanation: Explanation: As activators and repressors have a domain organization it is seen that if a DNA binding domain is provided it doesnÕt affect the activity. As long as the factor binds to the correct cis element it will still be a functional repressor.

Question: 9. Which of this element is not orientation independent?
Explanation: Explanation: While upstream activating element is orientation independent, enhancers and silencers are position as well as orientation independent. On the other hand promoter proximal elements are orientation dependent.

Question: 10. Which of these promoter elements has a high propensity of developing mutation given the eukaryotic gene was inserted in prokaryotes?
Explanation: Explanation: This is because prokaryotic methylases would methylate the C bases of the CPG region. Then it there is a de-amination of C base, it will resemble a T base which is not as easily distinguishable as U by UDG. So, this region is very mutagenic.

Question: 1.  RAP1 has a ___________________
Option D: d) Immensely positive effect on transcription
Explanation: Explanation: RAP1 is necessary for silencing at the telomere. As silenced gene canÕt be expressed so it has a negative effect. The effect can be even called very negative as the silencing is very strong.

Question: 2. We know that loss of DNA bases is highly mutagenic. But a loss of DNA bases from which region will not have much affect at all?
Explanation: Explanation: Telomere genes are mostly silenced so in case of any deletion mutation the deletion will not be detected. However, loss of bases from anywhere else in the chromosome which transcribe RNA could be disastrous for the cell.

Question: 4. Yeast mating factor alpha is located in _________________
Explanation: Explanation: The mating factor alpha is located in the left telomere at HML. This gets transferred to MAT locus for expression. HMR has the ÔaÕ mating factor.

Question: 5. If a parent yeast is of mating type a, what will be the mating type of its bud?
Explanation: Explanation: In yeast mating type alternates with every generation, so if a parent is ÔaÕ then bud will be ÔalphaÕ and vice versa. Yeast with a-alpha mating type is sterile while there is no rho mating type of yeast.

Question: 6. Under which condition will the yeast express a-alpha mating type?
Explanation: Explanation: HAT acetylates the histone H3 and H4 so it activates the gene while HDAC deacetylates them and inactivates the genes. Under condition when HAT is active but HDAC is inactive we will get an expression of both the telomere gene which is normally repressed. This will lead to a-alpha mating type.

Question: 7.  RAP1 binds to ____________
Option A: a) At the loop between enhancer and promoter
Option C: c) At the nuclosomes in telomere region
Explanation: Explanation: RAP1 has no sequence specification. It binds to the repeated sequences at the telomeric region in the linear DNA lacking nucleosomes. Then, it loops over and spreads the repression to the entire telomere.

Question: 8. Which of these SIR proteins are having HDAC activity?
Explanation: Explanation: The SIR or silent information regulator proteins are responsible for repression at the telomere by deacetylating the histones. While SIR3and SIR4 bind to the N-termini the SIR2 protein which is attracted by SIR 3-4 is having the HDAC activity.

Question: 9. You transfer the DAM gene to the telomere of yeast. What will be your expected result?
Option A: a) Methylation at the A sites in specific sequence
Option B: b) Methylation at the C sites in specific sequence
Option C: c) No methylation at the A sites in specific sequence
Option D: d) No methylation at the C sites in specific sequence
Explanation: Explanation: DAM is a methylase that methylates the A of GATC sequence. When expressed in Yeast it methylated the yeast DNA, however, in telomere the expression is blocked by the telomere silencing effect. Thus, we donÕt get methylated DNA.

Question: 10. What is the range of telomere suppression?
Explanation: Explanation: The telomere suppression spreads up to 4kb from the telomere. This is possible due to the looping action of RPA1 and SIR2-4 proteins by protein-protein interactions. The history at this regions are hemi-acetylated.

Question: 1.  In which of the following chromosome compaction is absent?
Explanation: Explanation: Cellulomonas flavigena is a prokaryote, and unlike the rest which are eukaryotes they donÕt have chromosome compaction and histones.

Question: 2. Histones are __________
Option D: d) Neutral with positive and negative domains
Explanation: Explanation: HIstones are rich in positively charged amino acids namely lysine and arginine. Thus they have a net positive charge. This helps them to bind to the negatively charged DNA.

Question: 3. Which of the following will increase transcription?
Option A: a) Shielding positive charge of DNA
Option B: b) Shielding positive charge of histones
Option C: c) Shielding promoter for polymerase binding
Explanation: Explanation: Histone binds to the negatively charged DNA due to its positive charges. On DNA binding those regions of the DNA are not available for transcription. Thus, shielding the positive charge would loosen this binding and enable more transcription.

Question: 4. Which histone(s) are acted upon by HAT?
Explanation: Explanation: These are the two histone residues that are having lysine side chains available for acetylation. On, HAT action they loosely bind to DNA allowing transcription.

Question: 5. In a substrate X catabolic gene promoter you replace the normal histones by your experimental histones Ð ones with arginine side chains in place of histidine. What will be the effect on the concentration of substrate X against the control?
Option D: d) Concentration will fluctuate and no definite result will be obtained
Explanation: Explanation: Arginine side chains canÕt be acetylated, so there is no regulation. They are always positively charged and never bind loosely so no gene product is produced. As these gene products are catabolic in their absence the substance X is not broken down so its concentration remains constant.

Question: 6. You take a crude cell lysate and treat it with DNase. Now wash it and add protease. Use specific restriction endonuclease to get your desired fragment and run it on a gel. You see a single band. Which of the following will be true about the fragment?
Option B: b) Only part of it is transcribed
Option C: c) No part of it transcribed
Explanation: Explanation: DNase would only get access to uncondensed DNA. Uncondensed DNA is transcriptionally active. As the DNase would have cleaved the fully or partially transcriptionally active DNA, and our fragment is intact, we can say it was not at all being transcribed.

Question: 7. Which of the following is not a common mode of histone modification in eukaryotes?
Explanation: Explanation: The positively charged N-termini of histone is modified by the phosphorylation, ubiquitinylation, methylation and also acetylation processes in order to shield its positive charges.

Question: 8.  Which of the following association acts as transcriptional activator?
Explanation: Explanation: When Max associates with Myc the gene is transcriptionally active, while when Max associates with Mad the gene is inactivated. This is because Mad binds to SIN3A which brings about a HDAC.

Question: 9. In an experiment you perform the following- you attach a flag epitope to HDAC, you over express a mutated Mad1-pro gene within the experimental cell, you immunoprecipitate the protein complex using flag epitope and run that on a non-denaturing SDS PAGE and western blot. Now you add antibodies for HDAC, MAD1 and SIN3A stripping after each addition. What will you observe?
Option A: a) Bands at same position every time
Option B: b) 3 bands at different positions one at a time
Option C: c) Bands at same position on 2 occasions
Explanation: Explanation: As Mad1-pro canÕt bind to SIN3A due to the mutation it will not precipitate with the HDAC-SIN3A complex. Due to non-denaturing nature of the gel both the proteins migrate together to the same distance so the band appears at the same position.

Question: 10. In presence of Thyroid hormone the receptor TR binds to ____________
Explanation: Explanation: In presence of thyroid hormone the receptor binds to RXR directly. In absence however, it binds to NcoR directly, which binds to SIN3 and mRPD3 which is an HDAC, this binding inactivates the genes.

Question: 1.  If the events in post transcriptional modification are listed as-
Option A: i) Polyadenylation   ii) capping   iii) splicing
Option B: What would be the correct sequence?
Explanation: Explanation: Post transcriptional modification is very strictly synchronized process and no next step takes place unless the preceding one is complete. The sequence is 1st adding cap, then Polyadenylation and then splicing.

Question: 2. Which RNA transcript would be capped by the capping enzymes in vitro mixture of RNA?
Option B: b) Pol I and Pol III transcripts
Option D: d) Pol I, Pol II and Pol III transcripts
Explanation: Explanation: In vivo, only pol II transcripts are capped, however in vitro when the different pol transcripts are mixed with the capping enzymes all of them are capped showing no specificity.

Question: 3. Which nucleotide is present in the 5Õ cap?
Explanation: Explanation: The 5Õ cap has a guanine residue which makes Gpp(pN)n where N is any nucleotide. This is also called the 5Õ G cap. Other bases like A, T, C or U donÕt participate in capping.

Question: 4. Which is the 1st enzyme in capping?
Explanation: Explanation: 1st the 5Õ triphosphate group is removed by the phosphatase. Then the Gpp is added to it making it the G cap. Lastly the methyl transferase transfers the methyl group to the N7 position of the cap guanine.

Question: 6. CBP acts as a(an)_______________
Explanation: Explanation: CBP acts as a catalyst which concentrates the enzyme activity at the pol II transcripts so that they are selectively capped at their 5Õ ends.

Question: 7. In an experiment you try to hybridize a Dna single strand with a mature RNA. You observe loops being formed. These loops have ____________
Explanation: Explanation: Due to splicing the mature mRNA is shorter than the DNA with the introns in DNA looping out when they hybridize. Thus the loops have DNA.

Question: 8. Which of the following corresponding to the same gene will you expect to be the shortest?
Explanation: Explanation: cDNA is made from reverse transcription of mRNA so it lacks the excess modifications present in mRNA. And as mRNA has only exons unlike hnRNA or DNA, cDNA would be the shortest of the four relating to the same gene.

Question: 9. Splicing concensus sequence is ___________
Explanation: Explanation: It has been seen that splicing occurs at this consensus sequence. However, as there could be many more motief similar to this within the intron there are additional consensus sequences.

Question: 10. In the consensus sequence 5_-AG/GUAAGUÐintronÐYNCURACÐYnNAG/G-3_  Y could be ______
Explanation: Explanation: Y could be any pyrimidine that rules out A and G as base. Now we know that RNA doesnÕt have T, so the only pyrimidine possible from the given combination is C.

Question: 1.  In an experiment, you are trying to pull down the site where guanyl transferase binds by co-immunoprecipitation. You run a gel and autoradiograph to see a band denoting GSK-RNA pol II (phosphorylated). What will you see when you perform the same experiment with overexpression of GSK in one setup and overexpression of unlabelled GSK-RNA pol II in the other setup?
Option A: a) Band is observed in both cases
Option B: b) Band in 1st case no band in 2nd
Option C: c) No band in 1st case and band in 2nd
Option D: d) No band in both cases
Explanation: Explanation: There will not be any change in the intensity of the 1st band as GT is not binding to GSK tag. The 2nd case also doesnÕt change the intensity of the band as GT binds to phosphorylated ÐGSK-RNA pol II, so no GT bound unlabelled RNA exists to compete with the labeled band and decrease its intensity.

Question: 2. The poly a tail protects the 3Õ end from____________
Explanation: Explanation: The 3Õ end of the RNA is susceptible to chewing by 3Õ->5Õ exonucleases. So, the poly A tail acts as a safeguard which even if chewed partly will protect the valuable information of the RNA. This in place of inhibition rather promotes the next steps like transcription and export.

Question: 3. Which of the following mRNA will not be polyadenylated?
Explanation: Explanation: Most of the mRNAs are polyadenylated except the major histone mRNAs. These are the canonical mRNA that need a rapid turnover and have a unique 3Õ end. However, the non-canonical mRNA produced during S phase are polyadenylated.

Question: 4. Which of the box is retained in mature mRNA?
Explanation: Explanation: The TATA box and Pribnow box are part of the promoter so they are not even transcribed into RNA. The GU box on the other hand is cleaved off during polyadenylation while the AU box is retained even after polyadenylation.

Question: 5. Which of these sequences will mark a site of polyadenylation?
Explanation: Explanation: The cleavage sequence has a consensus of AAUAAA sequence towards the 5Õ and a G/U box towards the 3Õ end and a CA dinucleotide in the middle. The cleavage is just after 3Õ to the CA.

Question: 6. Which of the following does not directly interact with DNA?
Explanation: Explanation: PAP binds to CPSF and CStF by protein-protein interaction and doesnÕt actually bind to the DNA. However, the other factors are cis elements binding to specific sequences.

Question: 7. CPSF and CStF bind to ____________
Option A: a) AAUAAA and G/U box respectively and bind is very strong
Option B: b) G/U box and AAUAAA respectively and bind is very strong
Option C: c) G/U box strongly but weakly AAUAAA
Option D: d) AAUAAA weakly but stabilization occurs after G/U binding
Explanation: Explanation: CPSF binds to AAUAAA but the interaction is weak. This interaction is strengthened by CStF binding to G/U box and further stabilization occurs at CFI and CFII binding.

Question: 8. PAP has a processivity of ___________
Explanation: Explanation: PAP has a very low processivity of about 10-20 A bases before binding of PABP II which has a very high processivity of 100 to 250 poly A bases.

Question: 9. Which experimental method can you use to detect 3Õ end processing?
Explanation: Explanation: An affinity chromatography using oligo T sephadex beads in the column can be used to detect proper 3Õ processing. If the RNA is properly processed the poly A tail will adhere to the oligo T and will not come out of the column without elution.

Question: 1.  IN case of splicing the attacking group is _________________
Explanation: Explanation: Splicing requires a branch point A that can attach the 5Õ end with the intron making a lariat structure. This doesnÕt require energy molecules like ATP.

Question: 2. In the case of group 1 RNA, which one of the following canÕt attack?
Explanation: Explanation: It is seen that in the case of group II auto splicing RNA the attack is made by the 3Õ-OH end of the ribose attached to the G base. It is immaterial whether its GMP, GDP or GTP. However, A base is not seen to attack in that case.

Question: 4. Choose the wrong answer.
Option A: a) The A base saves the 5Õ-P of the intron by forming bond which saves requirement of ATP
Option B: b) The 5Õ-P attacks the 3Õ-OH of the intron
Option C: c) In self splicing group I G base makes this lariet structure
Option D: d) Group II self-splicing RNA splices better when proteins are added
Explanation: Explanation: The G base attacking the 5Õ end of the intron doesnÕt form a bond with the 2ÕOH but with the 3Õ-OH end. Thus, in place of a leriet like structure a linear structure is seen.

Question: 5. Which of the following shows incorrect matching?
Explanation: Explanation: In the spliceosome complex we see that U1 is replaced by U6 and not U2. U2AF on the other hand is replaced by U2. Other matches but d are correct.

Question: 6. 5Õ______ and 3Õ ____ is the sequence for two ends of an intron.
Explanation: Explanation: The 5Õ end of the splice site has the sequence GU, the 3Õ end has the sequence AG. These help to locate the intron but more determining factors exist.

Question: 7. In the cytoplasm we can find ___________________ U rich snRNA.
Explanation: Explanation: U4 and U6 snRNA are found in the cytoplasm. They can associate to form a common RNP with the other proteins when they can move to the nucleus. In the nucleus, it interacts with U5 to form the tripartite complex.

Question: 8. Which of the following is retained in the C complex of splicosome?
Explanation: Explanation: The C complex is the final structure before the attack. Then U6 has replaced U1 and U2 has replaced U2AF and U4 dissociates. Only U5 is still there stabilizing the structure by binding the two ends to close.

Question: 9. Proteins rich in _____________ and ______________ help in splicing.
Explanation: Explanation: The proteins rich in Serine (S) and Arginine (R) are needed for proper splicing. FG rich proteins on the other hand are seen in the nucleoporin complex.

Question: 10. The SR proteins bind to the __________________
Option B: b) Introns not to be skipped
Option D: d) Exons not to be skipped
Explanation: Explanation: Binding of SR proteins on the exons ensure that the exon is not skipped. It doesnÕt bind to intron and in some weak exons it helps in skipping the exon thus helping in alternate splicing.

Question: 11. SR proteins can interacts with__________________
Explanation: Explanation: SR protein interacts with U1 and helps it to recognize the 5Õ end. It also interacts with the U2AF that helps to bind it to the branch point.

Question: 13. Which of the following is the proper sequence of assembly of factors on the branch poinr A?
Explanation: Explanation: BBP stands for branch point binding proteins. In the branch site A 1st the U2AF binds followed by BBP then it is replaced by U2. Then U2 can interact with U6 that replaced U1.

Question: 14. ESE bound to SR proteins ______________ splicing and ESE bound to hnRNA ______________ splicing.
Explanation: Explanation: Binding of SR proteins to ESE or exon splicing enhancers promotes splicing where that exon is retained. hnRNA is a competitive inhibitor of SR proteins that tend to bind ESE as well, thus it inactivates.

Question: 15. U rich RNA that helps in splicing are______________
Explanation: Explanation: The U rich NA are the small nuclear or snRNA. The snoRNA are needed for ribosomal rRNA processing in the nucleolus. hnRNA is heterogeneous nuclear RNA are mRNA is the RNA that is spliced by snRNA.

Question: 1. Which of the following codon calls for fMettRNA ÐfMet?
Explanation: Explanation: AUG is the start codon for translation, and it incorporates formyl methinonyl tRNA to start translation. The 1st base is always an f-Met although it may be later cleaved off.

Question: 3. What is meant by degenerate codon?
Option A: a) Two codons can be read in different frame o give different amino acids
Option B: b) Codons are not having a gap
Option C: c) Specific codon codes for specific amino acid
Option D: d) Two codons can code for same amino acid
Explanation: Explanation: Degeneracy means that there can be two or more codons that can code for same amino acid with there being triplet codon and 4 bases there are 64 possible combinations and only 20 amino acids. This was then observed that different codon could be degenerate i.e. code for same amino acid.

Question: 4. Consider that our codon in place of being triplet was quadruplet. How many possible combinations could be there then?
Explanation: Explanation: There are 4 DNA bases and triplet coodon so number of possible combinations id 43=64. Now if the codon was quadruplet the combinations would be 44=256.

Question: 5. Which of the following is not a stop codon?
Explanation: Explanation: GUG is not a stop codon, rather it is a start codon which can be used in place of AUG. On the other hand UAA, UAG and UGA are stop codons.

Question: 6. In an experiment if you add poly A oigon-dNTP in a nucleotide free cell lysate. Which of the labeled amino acid do you expect to be incorporated in the peptide so formed?
Explanation: Explanation: While poly A oligo-rNTP would incorporate lysine, due to repeated AAA codon, oligo-dNTP actually makes poly U oligo-rNTP, having codon UUU that codes for Phenyl alanine.

Question: 7. Wooble base hypothesis is applicable to the____________
Explanation: Explanation: Wooble hypothesis states that the 1st anticodon of the tRNA is not very specific. So it can pair with upto 3 different bases in the codons 3rd position.

Question: 8. If you consider wooble hypothesis I in 1st position of anticodon can not pair with?
Option A: a) A is 3rd position of codon
Option B: b) U is 3rd position of codon
Option C: c) G is 3rd position of codon
Option D: d) C is 3rd position of codon
Explanation: Explanation: I is the ionosine base that can pair with A, U and C in the 3rd position of the codon. But it canÕt pair with G or itself.

Question: 10. Which of these mutations will have the least harmful effect?
Explanation: Explanation: In all possibilities transition of a base would have least harmful effect as there are degenerate codons for same amino acid. The new codon could thus be a silent mutation. Also if it is the 3rd base due to wooble hypothesis it will have negligible effect.

Question: 11. If you charge a lys-tRNA with an alanine, what amino acid will you expect to be incorporated against AAA?
Explanation: Explanation: The anticodon loop plays no part in recognizing the amino acid. It can simply recognize the codon. So, it will call in the Ala charged lysine-tRNA to alysine AAA codon and add the alanine to the peptide.

Question: 1. In eukaryotes tRNA are transcribed by ________
Explanation: Explanation: The RNA polymerase III transcribes the tRNA in eukaryotes while in prokaryotes there is only one RNA polymerase for all type of RNA.

Question: 2. The tertiary structure of the tRNA is __________
Explanation: Explanation: The tertiary structure of the tRNA is L shaped while the secondary structure is cloverleaf shaped. The tRNA has three stem loop structures.

Question: 3. Which one of this is not a normal base found in tRNA?
Explanation: Explanation: Unlike most RNA tRNA has some special bases like pseudo uridine, dihydroxy uridine etc. But oxoG is a base produced due to oxidative damage, it is not normally found in RNA.

Question: 4. What is the amino acid binding sequence in tRNA?
Explanation: Explanation: The CCA sequence of the aminoacyl arm of tRNA is responsible for binding the amino acid. While AUG is a start codon and T _ C is another arm of the tRNA.

Question: 5. Which arm of the tRNA can act as a structural recognition feature?
Explanation: Explanation: The variable arm, as its name suggest, differs for different tRA. Some amino acyltRNA synthetase can use them as recognition feature.

Question: 6. Class II amino acyl tRNA synthetase transfers the amino acids to the tRNA __________
Explanation: Explanation: Class II aminoacyl tRNA synthetase transfers the amino acid to the 2Õ-OH of the tRNA. There is a quick equilibrium between the 2Õ and the 3Õ-OH. On the other hand class I amino acyl tRNA synthetase transfers it to the 3Õ-OH.

Question: 7. Which of the following tRNA is charged by class II aminoacyl tRNA synthetase?
Explanation: Explanation: Asp is charged by class II amino acyl tRNA synthetase. It recognized the structural features and not the anticodon loop, there is also no bending of the 3Õ-OH end of the amino acyl arm.

Question: 8. In an experiment you charge a tRNA with a wrong base. You allow the mixture to stand for a while. What will you expect to see?
Explanation: Explanation: Certain synthetases can cleave the bond between wrong amino acid and the tRNA. This is a type of proofreading mechanism that ensures correct amino acid incorporation.

Question: 10. What is the amino acid present in the binding pocket of glutaminyl amino acyl tRNA synthetase?
Explanation: Explanation: The 3Õ-OH of the aminoacyl arm of the tRNA enters the binding pocket of the synthetase to interact with a Gln amino acid correctly placed. This is used to distinguish it from Asp and Asn.

Question: 1.  Eukaryotic ribosomal subunits are _____________
Explanation: Explanation: The eukaryotic ribosomal subunits are 40S and 60S and together they make 80S. On the other hand the prokaryotic ribosomal subunits are 30S and 50S making 70S.

Question: 2. Which of these is transcribed by RNA pol III?
