Explanation: Explanation: While most of the eukaryotic rRNAs are transcribed by the RNA pol I, the 5S rRNA is transcribed by RNA pol III. 16S rRNA is however absent in eukaryotes.

Question: 3. If you gradually decrease the Mg2+ concentration of the solution of ribosomes, what will you expect?
Option A: a) The subunits will associate faster
Option C: c) rRNA will separate from its protein
Option D: d) The two subunits will dissociate into its rRNA
Explanation: Explanation: Low Mg2+ concentration facilitates dissociation of the subunits of RNA polymerases. On the contrary increasing Mg2+ concentration will promote association in vitro.

Question: 4. Which of this is not a ribosomal protein?
Explanation: Explanation: While naming the ribosomal proteins L and S stand for larger and smaller subunits respectively. The larger subunit has 34 proteins while the smaller one has 21, so there could not be S34 protein in the ribosome.

Question: 5. Which ribosome recognized the transcription initiation site of the mRNA?
Explanation: Explanation: The 18S rRNA of a smaller subunit for eukaryotes and the 16S rRNA of the smaller subunit for prokaryotes recognizes the mRNA initiation site.

Question: 6. The ribosomal peptidyl transferase transfers ___________
Option A: a) An isolated amino acid to the peptide chain
Option B: b) A peptide chain to an amino acid
Option C: c) A peptide chain to another peptide chain
Option D: d) An amino acid to a tRNA
Explanation: Explanation: Ribosomal peptidyl transferase transfers a peptide chain over the tRNA in P site of the ribosome to the tRNAÕs amino acid in the A site of the same ribosome.

Question: 7. The tRNA f-Met-tRNA binds to __________
Explanation: Explanation: f-Met tRNA actually binds to normal methionine (there is no readily available f-Met), then N10-formyl-THF converts that methionine to f-Met.

Question: 8. Which metal acts as a cofactor for Methionyl aminopeptidase?
Explanation: Explanation: The Methionyl aminopeptidase which removes the terminal methionine residue in the peptide chain uses Co2+ as a cofactor. While on the other hand many polymerase use Mg2+  and DNA binding domain uses Zn2+.

Question: 9. Methionine amino peptidase will remove the N terminal formyl methionine if the N+1 amino acid is_________
Explanation: Explanation: The N terminal amino acid can be removed only if the N+1 amino acid is small, i.e. Gly, Ala, Ser, Thr, Pro, Val or Cys. Here all other than Glycine are larger amino acid. So, only glycine in the N+1 position will suffice the result.

Question: 10. The f-Met tRNA binds to ribosomal _______ site
Explanation: Explanation: fMettRNA-fMet binds to the P site of the ribosome in translational initiation and then the site is blocked by initiation factor.

Question: 11. The 50S ribosomal subunit is folded in ______ major domains.
Explanation: Explanation: While the smaller 30S subunit of the ribosome is folded into 4 major domains the larger 50S subunit had 6 major domains with its 23S and 5S rRNA.

Question: 13. The Shine and Dalgarno is located in ____________
Option A: a) 5.8S rRNA ~ 20 nucleotide upstream to start site
Option B: b) mRNA ~ 10 nucleotide upstream to start site
Option C: c) 16S rRNA ~ 10 nucleotide upstream to start site
Option D: d) 23S rRNA ~ 10 nucleotide upstream to start site
Explanation: Explanation: The 16S rRNA forms the smaller subunit which recognizes the mRNA via its Shine and Dalgarno sequence. This is a purine rich sequence about 10 amino acids upstream to translation start site.

Question: 1.  The catalytic activity of the ribosome is located in the ______
Explanation: Explanation: The peptidyl transferase activity of the ribosome is located in the 50S subunit of the ribosome in the rRNA and not in the protein. This has been supported with sound proof.

Question: 2. Puromycin is a ribosomal antibiotic. It binds to ________
Option D: d) A site of unassociated 16S rRNA
Explanation: Explanation: Puromycinis a tRNA analogue that has an amide bond in place of ester bond. This is why when the ribosome transfers the peptide over this; it flees with the peptide and stops the translation.

Question: 3. In an experiment you add rifampicin and paramomycin to the ribosome and mRNA mixture. What will inhibit theribosomal translation efficiency and how?
Option A: a) Rifampicin will prevent translation initiation
Option B: b) Paramomycin will slow down translation
Option C: c) Rifampicin will bind irreversibly to the ribosome and inactivate it
Option D: d) Paramomycin will increase error rate
Explanation: Explanation: Paramomycin acts as a ribosomal translation inhibitor while Rifampicin acts on RNA polymerase. Paramomycin actually increases the error rate of the translation thus producing wrong nonfunctional proteins ultimately killing the bacteria.

Question: 4. Which antibiotic inhibits peptidyl transfer by blocking the accommodation of aa-tRNA into the peptidyl transferase (A/A) site?
Explanation: Explanation: While chloramphenicol also blocks the peptidyl transferase activity, tetracycline does so by blocking the A site. Then the A site amino acid canÕt interact with the P site one for the reaction to take place.

Question: 5. Which of the antibiotic can halt translocation of the ribosome bound to the mRNA?
Explanation: Explanation: Fusidic acid inhibits elongation in prokaryotes in a way that it binds to Ef-G-GDP permanently and doesnÕt allow the ribosome to fall off.

Question: 7. In an experiment you add streptomycin at low concentration first and then gradually increase the concentration till it completely inhibits peptide formation. What will be its effect at low concentration?
Explanation: Explanation: Streptomycin interacts with the smaller subunit of the ribosome and prevents the initiation at higher concentration. At lower concentration, it leads to the incorporation of more errors.

Question: 8. What will be DNA sequence of Shine and Dalgarno coding region?
Explanation: Explanation: As the Shina and Dalgarno region is purine rich i.e. A/G rich, its corresponding DNA sequence should be pyrimidine rich or C/T rich. This is because a purine base pairs with a pyrimine so a Pyrimidine will code for a purine in RNA.

Question: 1. In an experiment you grow some cells in a media containing heavy isotopes of C and N. Then you transfer then to a lighter media. If you centrifuge the ribosomes so obtained after an hour how many bands will you expect?
Explanation: Explanation: You will obtain 4 bands corresponding to heavy 50 and 30S subunit, heavy 50S and light 30S subunit, heavy 30S and light 50S subunit and light 50S and 30S subunit respectively.

Question: 2. In an experiment you stall the ribosome with low Mg2+ concentration. Which of the following will then cause the release of the Peptide from the ribosome?
Explanation: Explanation: Pyromycin will cause the release of peptide with pyromycin at the C terminus. On the other hand urea will simply degrade the pepide.

Question: 3. What discovery was stated by Robert Traut and Munro experiment?
Option A: a) 30S subunit is binding to IF
Option B: b) 50S subunit has peptidy transferase activity
Option C: c) rRNA has peptifyl transfer activity
Option D: d) Urea prevents peptide bond formation
Explanation: Explanation: In Robert Traut and Munro experiment puromycin was used as an assay of peptidyl transfer activity. They observed that rRNA was able to transfer the amino acid chain from tRNA on P site to the aminoacyl tRNA on A site.

Question: 4. What was the unnatural experimental condition which proved to be a criticism in Robert Traut and Munro experiment?
Option A: a) Use of low Mg2+ concentration
Explanation: Explanation: The condition of 33% methanol is not usual for a celluar interior. Thus Robert Traut and MunroÕs using 33% methanol (or ethanol) to carry out peptidyl transfer activity was criticized.

Question: 5. Which of the following was not a protein degrading agent used by Noller in his experiment?
Explanation: Explanation: In NollerÕs experiment ribosomes were strongly treated with protein degrading agents like phenol, SDS etc; but urea was not one of them.

Question: 6. You gradually treat ribosome with SDS followed by Proteinase K and the finally extract it with phenol. Which of the options match the result you expect?
Option A: a) Ribosome withstands all these treatments and still has peptidyl transferase activity
Option B: b) It stands upto SDS treatment
Option C: c) It stands no treatment at all
Option D: d) It stands upto proteinase K treatment
Explanation: Explanation: Ribosomes treated by SDS and proteinase K shows a remarkable ability to still carryout peptidyl transfer activity. However, extraction with phenol destroys this activity. This may be because it disturbs some higher order structure.

Question: 7. How many proteins were still intact after the treatment of ribosome with SDS and proteinase K?
Explanation: Explanation: Even after such harsh treatment with SDS and proteinase K, 8 proteins were still retained in the ribosome. If they are removed by phenol treatment the peptidyl transfer activity is lost as they support some tertiary or quaternary structure.

Question: 8. What is the distance between the catalytic site and the nearest protein in the ribosome?
Explanation: Explanation: There is a gap of 50 angestron between the catalytic site of the ribosome and the nearest protein to that point. This ensures that the catalytic activity is due to the rRNA and not any protein as proteins canÕt influence a reaction 50 angestron away from it.

Question: 10. Aminoglycosides can kill_______________
Option C: c) Only anerobic gram positive bacteria
Option D: d) Only aerobic gram negative bacteria
Explanation: Explanation: Aminoglycosides are the group of antibiotic that can kill gram negative bacteria which are aerobic. Some of such antibiotics are Streptomycin, Paramomycin etc.

Question: 11. In evolutionary history which of the following rose 1st?
Explanation: Explanation: RNA was the 1st to arise which served both as information storage and as enzyme namely ribozyme. Later it transferred the activities to more specific molecules namely DNA and protein respectively.

Question: 1.  The 16S rRNA binds the mRNA in its ___________ region.
Explanation: Explanation: The 3Õ-OH end of the 16S rRNA is located in the neck region of the rRNA. Near it is the Shine and Dalgarno sequence that binds the mRNA.

Question: 2. _____________ treated ribosomes will be able to carry out elongation and termination of previously initiated translation, but canÕt initiate any new translation.
Explanation: Explanation: Colicin e# effects initiation at the Shine and Dalgarno sequence, however, it has no effect on elongation of termination. Thus, it will prevent new initiation but will not halt already translating ribosomes.

Question: 3. IF1 helps in correct placement of the initiation tRNA. How does it do so?
Option A: a) By guiding it to P site
Option B: b) By binding to A site
Option C: c) By dissociating the ribosomal complex
Option D: d) By binding to the P site
Explanation: Explanation: IF1 binds to the A site of the 30S subunit so that the 1st aminoacyl-tRNA canÕt sit at the A site. It then sits on the P site i.e. correct position.

Question: 4. Which initiation factor prevents association of ribosome when not bound to mRNA?
Explanation: Explanation: The IF3 binds to the 30S subunit and prevents association of 30S and 50S subunit when the ribosome is not bound to mRNA. It also helps in binding t the mRNA.

Question: 5. If you see a GTP bound IF2 it is _________
Option D: d) Not related to an initiation
Explanation: Explanation: IF2 guides the 1st tRNA to the P site of the ribosome. Then it is GTP bound. When properly placed the GTP hydrolyses to GDP and the IF2 is released.

Question: 6. Which proteins perform the function of preventing reassociation of ribosomal subunits, when they finish one translation, in eukaryotes?
Explanation: Explanation: eIF1 is a multi protein complex with eight subunits; this along with eIF6 prevents the reassociation of the subunits of ribosome after translation of one protein is complete.

Question: 7. What is used to regulate translation initiation in eukaryotes?
Explanation: Explanation: Phosphorylation of IF2 prevents it from binding to f-MettRNA-f-Met, thus it prevents initiation of translation by IF2 bringing the 1st amino acid.

Question: 8. If you compare the Kozak sequence with the SD sequence of the prokaryotes which is located at the greater distance from the start site?
Option D: d) Both are too far to account
Explanation: Explanation: Eukaryotes are not polycistronic and the 5Õ cap corresponds to the 5Õ end of the mRNA near which it must start translating. Although there is not much defined sequence but all the same there is a consensus.

Question: 9. Which of the bases are important in detecting whether the AUG should be the start site for eukaryotic initiation?
Explanation: Explanation: The consensus sequence CC(A/G)CCAUGG was discovered by Kozak, where the purine in -3 and +4 position is significant in determining which AUG should serve as initiation site.

Question: 10. If give a segment Ð 5ÕCTGACCAUGGCCTAGAUGCCTCT, which AUG will the eukaryotic ribosome choose as initiation site?
Explanation: Explanation: The ribosome scans the mRNA from 5Õ end to the 3Õ end searching for a Kozak consensus sequence to start at. Here, the 1st AUG indeed has a purin at -3 and +4 position so it is a good initiation site, the ribosome will not look beyond to the 2nd AUG(weaker) and start initiation.

Question: 1. Which initiation factor in eukaryotes recognizes the 7-M-G cap?
Explanation: Explanation: eIF4E recognized the 7-Methyl Guanine cap in the 5Õ end of mRNA. This interacts with eIF4G and eIF3 which slides the 40S subunit on the mRNA looking for an initiation site.

Question: 2. Which of the following will not affect translation from the AUG involved?
Option A: a) A short hairpin near the cap
Option B: b) A hairpin 52 at downstream of cap
Option C: c) A long hairpin between cap and initiation codon
Option D: d) Providing a purine at -3 and +4 position of a start codon
Explanation: Explanation: It has been seen experimentally that a hairpin 52 at further from the cap canÕt help the AUG to be recognized as initiation site even when the AUG is within it. The other options here improve translation from the AUG involved.

Question: 3. IRES interact with which of the initiation factors?
Explanation: Explanation: IRES is the Internal Ribosome Entry Site, this is recognized by a protein called protein X, which is further recognized by eIF4G.

Question: 4. Polysomes are ______________
Explanation: Explanation: Polysomes are the chromosomes on with a number of ribosomes are translating the same gene in a series. These tend to appear circular as that helps in recycling the ribosomes from the poly A tai to the initiation site.

Question: 5. Which poly a tail binding protein helps in the initiation of translation?
Explanation: Explanation: PABP2 can bind the poly a tail to the eIF4E through the mediator eIF4G. This increases the association of the 40S subunit to the 5Õ end of the mRNA thus increasing translation.

Question: 6. Which of the following is not a part of eIF4F complex?
Explanation: Explanation: eIF4F is the complex that assembles at the 5Õ methylated guanine cap of the mRNA to initiate translation. It has three factors eIF4A, eIF4G and eIF4E while eIF4B is not a factor of this complex.

Question: 7. Which of the following factors prevent reassociation of the 40S and 60S subunits when not bound to the mRNA?
Explanation: Explanation: While he factor eIF3 binds to the 40S subunit, the other factor eIF6 binds to the 60S subunit and prevent the association of ribosomal subunits when not bound to mRNA.

Question: 8. Which one of the following has GEF activity?
Explanation: Explanation: The factor eIF2B is a Guanosine nucleotide Exchange Factor or GEF. It exchanges the GDP bound to eIF2 to GTP so that it can then bind to the aminoacyl tRNA.

Question: 9. Phosphorylation of eIF4E-BP will affect translation in what way?
Option D: d) There is no such factor
Explanation: Explanation: eIF4E-BP is the active form of the factor which can bind to the eIF4E and prevent translation. When phosphorylated, this binding is sterically prevented. Thus, phosphorylation increases translation generating free eIF4E.

Question: 10. Which of the following is done by HCR?
Explanation: Explanation: HCR is Heme Controlled Repressor protein which senses the lack of heme in the medium and phosphorylated eIF2-alpha. This prevents the GEF activity of eIF2B and prevents translation. This measure prevents the waste of resources.

Question: 1.  Which of the elongation factor binds to amino acyl tRNA?
Explanation: Explanation: EF-Tu in GTP bound form binds to amino acyl tRNA. It helps to bring the amino acid to the ribosome, and one placed in proper position the GTP hydrolyses.

Question: 2. EF-Tu GTP complex is ____________
Explanation: Explanation: The GTP bound form of EF-Tu is so stable that it needs another factor EF-Ts to break it down and reattach it to another GTP.

Question: 3. After the Ef-G cycle the A site_________
Explanation: Explanation: The EF-G factor helps in translocation of the ribosome such that the peptide bound tRNA shifts to the P site and A site becomes empty and available to bind another charged tRNA.

Question: 4. The E site of the ribosome has a high affinity for___________
Explanation: Explanation: From the A site and the P site, the tRNA moves to the E site or exit site. Then its tRNA is deacylated as the peptide bond is on the P site tRNA.

Question: 5. What is the rate of translation in prokaryotes under adequate conditions?
Explanation: Explanation: While the ribosome can read about 50-60 nucleotides per second, due to triplet codon the maximum number of amino acids added per second would be : (60/3) = 20 amino acid per second.

Question: 6. According to the hybrid state model, if we consider the hybrid state of a tRNA such that its base is bound to the P site of 30S subunit, where will its head be bound?
Explanation: Explanation: According to hybrid model 1st the head part shifts to the next site in the cycle then the foot part of tRNA bound to 30S subunit shifts along with the input of energy. Thus, according to our question the head should be at E site.

Question: 7. If a peptide is 160 amino acids long, How many GTP and ATP molecules does it use for elongation?
Explanation: Explanation: There are 159 translation steps from initiation to termination. Each step has an input of 2 GTP in form of EF-Tu and Ef-G. For all 160 amino acids we have to charge it with 160 ATP.

Question: 8. How many factors play a role in termination of translation?
Explanation: Explanation: The factors are- RF1-3, RRF and Ef-G respectively. The EF-G factor finally hydrolyses the GTP that leads to final translocation step freeing the ribosome.

Question: 9. Which of these factors can recognize the UAA stop codon?
Explanation: Explanation: RF1 (as well as RF2) can recognize the stop codons at the A site. They can recognize the UAA and UAG stop codons on the mRNA.

Question: 10. Binding of RF3.GTP to the ribosome helps in release of the ____________
Explanation: Explanation: RF3.GTP binds the ribosome after the peptide is already released by the RF1. It hydrolyses to release the RF1 instead.

Question: 11. Which factor or factors lead to the ultimate disassembly of the ribosomal complex?
Explanation: Explanation: The RRF first replaces the RF3 from the termination complex. Then, EF-G translocates the complex for the last time freeing the mRNA, Ribosome, tRNA and the factors.

Question: 12. Which factors lead to disassociation of the ribosomal subunits?
Explanation: Explanation: While the release factor releases the ribosome from the termination complex, in order to keep the ribosome functional the 50S and 30S subunits should be separated. This is maintained by IF1 and IF3 (mainly by IF3) which prevents re-association.

Question: 1.  What is the eukaryotic homologue for EF-G?
Explanation: Explanation: The eukaryotic homologue for EF-G is EF2 while homologue for EF-Tu is EF1. These are the elongation factors that interact with the ribosome.

Question: 2. The eukaryotic initiation codon recognizes________
Explanation: Explanation: The initiation of translation in eukaryotes is by the codon AUG that recognizes initiation tRNA or tRNAi that binds to methionine. While in prokaryotes it is by formyl met tRNA which binds to met and converts it to formyl met.

Question: 3. EF2 structurally mimics_______
Explanation: Explanation: EF-2 should structurally mimic EF-1 such that it binds near the A site, and on GTP hydrolysis it can give the push to the tRNA at the A site of the ribosome to translocate it.

Question: 5. What is the final factor in eukaryotes that releases the peptide and ribosome?
Explanation: Explanation: The RF3 is responsible for cleavage of the peptide bond as well as for the release of the ribosomal subunits in eukaryotes.

Question: 7. Which of the following will effectively cause normal translation from an initiation AUG, blocked by a strong AUG upstream?
Option A: a) Hairpin loop near the 1st AUG
Option C: c) In frame stop codon between two AUGs
Option D: d) Deletion of the GAP between the two AUGs
Explanation: Explanation: If there is in frame stop codon to 1st AUG there will be an open reading frame in between 1st AUG and stop codon and again another open reading frame from 2nd AUG. This will lead to effectively normal translation from the 2nd AUG.

Question: 8. In Eukaryotes the region between 1st AUG and 5Õ-G cap is known as ___________
Explanation: Explanation: The UTR or untranslated region is the region near the 5Õ end and 3Õ end of the monocystronic eukaryotic mRNA that is not translated. From the AUG onwards s the Open reading frame or ORF which is translated till the stop codon.

Question: 9. The AU rich regions on the stem loop structure of IRE ____________
Explanation: Explanation: The stem loop structures in the 3Õ end in the UTR of the mRNA for transferring has some stem loop structures with the loop being rich in AU bases. These loops call in the protein responsible for degrading the mRNA increasing its turnover.

Question: 10. IRE-BP does not bind to _______________
Option B: b) Stem loop in 5Õ end of Ferritin
Option C: c) Stem loop in 3Õ end of Transferrin
Option D: d) AU rich regions in IRE
Explanation: Explanation: IRES stands for Internal ribosomal entry site, which in no way is related to iron sensing. The AU rich regions in IRE are actually the step loop in 3Õ end of transferring that binds to IRE-BP. Also, the stem loop in 5Õ end of ferritin binds IRE-BP.

Question: 1.  Mitogens can control translation efficiency by acting on _____________ factor which ___________
Option A: a) eIF4 factors which increases translation
Option B: b) eIF4A factors which decreases translation
Option C: c) eIF4E factors which increases translation
Option D: d) eIF4G factors which decreases translation
Explanation: Explanation: Mitogens cause phosphorylation of eIF4E-BP which binds to eIF4E and prevents translation. Thus, phosphorylation of the inhibitor will in turn promote translation.

Question: 2. In an experiment with the effect of insulin on the protein synthesis, which of the factors doesnÕt play a role?
Explanation: Explanation: During insulin signalling, the receptor which has an intrinsic tyrosine kinase property activates mTOR, which phosphorylates and inhibits PHAS1 thus releasing eIF4E for increasing translation.

Question: 3. Which of the following acts as a GAP during translation?
Explanation: Explanation: While the eIF2B has a GEF activity, the eIF5 promotes the phosphatase activity of eIF5B. This helps the GTP to hydrolysis to GDP thus helping in dissociation of tRNAi and initiation of translation.

Question: 4. In a synergistic model of initiation which of the following factor doesnÕt directly lead to initiation?
Explanation: Explanation: In a synergistic model of initiation both the poly a tail and the G cap plays a role. So, PAB1 binds to the poly A tail and eIF4E binds to the 5Õ-G cap with the eIF4G acting as a linker. But protein X plays a role in IRES mode of initiation not this.

Question: 5. When the intracellular iron level is low, the turnover of transferrin mRNA is________
Explanation: Explanation: By turnover of mRNA the effective concentration of a protein can be decreased as it reduces the chance of translation. When already the level of iron is low, more transferring s required, so mRNA is stabilized and its turnover is reduced.

Question: 6. The production of casein by rat mammary gland tissue reduces 100 fold in the absence of prolactin hormone. This reduction is due to_____________
Option A: a) Binding of eIF4E by PHAS 1
Option B: b) Greater turnover of mRNA for casein
Option C: c) Lesser synthesis of casein mRNA
Option D: d) Development of secondary structure on mRNA preventing translation
Explanation: Explanation: It has been seen in vitro that treatment with prolactin only increases the production of casein mRNA to 3 fold, but there is an increase of 100 fold in casein level. So, this must be due to an increase in stability by the change in protein turnover rate.

Question: 7. In an experiment if you take a stretch of hybridized RNA, and add only eIF4A, eIF4B and eIF4a and eIF4B together what will happen to the band obtained by that fragment under SDS.
Option A: a) Slight rise, no rise, appearance of two bands one on top of original
Option B: b) No rise in all cases but appearance of a 2nd band on top of 1st in 3rd case
Option C: c) Slight rise, slightly more rise, and highest rise
Option D: d) A faint band above the original, only original and a dark band above original
Explanation: Explanation: Rise in a band is seen only in case of EMSA which is not performed in this experiment. Here eIF4A acts as a helicase separating the dimer into monomer which leads to the formation of an upper band. eIF4B is a promoter of helicase activity of eIF4A in absence of which there is only slight activity.

Question: 8. Translation of which sigma factor is dependent on a genetic thermostat?
Explanation: Explanation: When the temperature is favorable the sigma 32 gene is hidden from initiation by complex mRNA structure. When the temperature rises, this complex opens up stabilizing the mRNA of sigma 32 thus leading to increase in its translation. This is like a genetic thermostat.

Question: 9. In an experiment you delete a part of the 5Õ UTR of transferring mRNA, what will be its effect on iron sensitivity?
Option A: a) It will be able to sense iron changes better
Option B: b) It will not be able to sense the iron changes
Option D: d) It will have leaky sensitivity
Explanation: Explanation: The IRE, or iron response elements of the transferring gene is located at the 3Õ end of the mRNA near the poly A tail. Thus, deletion of a part in 5Õend will have no effect at all.

Question: 10. The Stem loop structures at the 5Õ UTR of Ferritin is not ______________
Explanation: Explanation: The 5Õ UTR of the Ferritin can also bind to IRE-BP when iron concentration is low. In that case the translation is prevented. But it is not AU rich so, it is not degraded.

Question: 11. Which of these is not an NMD factor?
Explanation: Explanation: NMD stands for nonsense mediated degradation which is responsible for degrading the mRNA prematurely when it has a nonsense mutation. Nonsense mutation can lead to a stop codon before the original stop codon. Here the only exonuclease also participates in normal turn over.

Question: 12. Which of the following is the correct sequence of turnover?
Option B: b) Exonucleolytic degradation, deadenylation and decapping
Option D: d) Decapping, deadenylation and exonucleolytic degradation
Explanation: Explanation: The turn-over of the mRNA proceeds in the following sequence- 1st the poly A tail is degraded i.e. deadenylation. Then the 5ÕG cap is removed i.e. decapping. The mRNA is degraded by the exonucleases.

Question: 2. Which of the following is not a point mutation?
Explanation: Explanation: Point mutation concerns a single base. Thus substitution, which includes transversion, and insertion or deletion, falls within point mutation. On the other hand, translocation involves a stretch of bases so it is not a point mutation.

Question: 3. ÔDelicious applesÕ canÕt be propagated through_____________
Explanation: Explanation: Delicious apple was produced first as a somatic mutation within a branch and was since propagated vegetatively. As somatic mutations donÕt affect germ cells, it canÕt be propagated through seeds.

Question: 4. Which of the following harmful mutations will have the most severe effect in the progeny?
Option A: a) Mutation in a muscle tissue
Option C: c) Mutation in sperm mother cells
Option D: d) Mutation in mammary gland tissue
Explanation: Explanation: Option a and d are somatic tissue, their mutation will not be propagated. A single gamete will only have a slight chance to fertilize and lead to mutation, but sperm mother mutation will produce many lethal gametes that will increase the probability.

Question: 5. The number of times a particular mutation occurs in a population of cells or individuals is known as __________
Explanation: Explanation: While mutation frequency is the number of times a particular mutation occurs in a population, mutation rate is the probability of a particular type of mutation per unit time.

Question: 6. Total number of transition and transversion that can take place in genome is___________
Explanation: Explanation: Transition is the replacement of a purine by another purine or a pyrimidine by another pyrimidine. Transversion is the replacement of a purine by a pyrimidine, or a pyrimidine by a purine. So there are 4 possible transition AÑG and CÑ T, and 8 possible transversions AÑC, AÑT, GÑC, GÑT.

Question: 7. Sickle cell anemia is a result of _______________
Explanation: Explanation: In this disease, a GAG is converted to a GUG, i.e a glutamic acid is converted to a valine. This is example of a mis-sense mutation where a change of base codes for a different amino acid from the original.

Question: 8. A frame shift mutation will have minimum effect when it leads to ______________
Explanation: Explanation: Frame shift mutations lead to lease effect when they lead to an insertion or deletion of 3 bases, as due to our codon being triplet this doesnÕt shift the reading frame. However, if the codon thus lost or added is a very important one in the gene, there could be serious consequences.

Question: 9. Wooble base recognition of the tRNAs in translation ignores which of the mutation?
Explanation: Explanation: Silent mutation is the one where two codons code for the same gene. Thus, conversion of one codon to another doesnÕt effectively change the protein at all.

Question: 10. Which of the following is a neutral mutation?
Option A: a) Replacement of a Glu by Val
Option B: b) Replacement of AAA by UAA
Option C: c) Replacement of Lys by Arg
Option D: d) Replacement of Thr by Tyr
Explanation: Explanation: Lys and Arg are both basic amino acid of similar size, thus the mutation of one with another doesnÕt have much effect on the final protein structure or function. On the other hand, option b is a nonsense mutation, and a and d are missense mutation.

Question: 11. Which of the following is a result of a sense mutation?
Option C: c) Mutation in beta globin leading to abnormal clotting and bleeding
Explanation: Explanation: In Thalassemia the alpha globin is 141 amino acids long as the UAA codon is changed to CAA, i.e a stop codon is changed to a glutamic acid. While sickle cell anemia is due to a mis sense mutation and c is due to a nonsense mutation and d due to trisomy.

Question: 12. Which of the following can act as an intragenic suppressor mutation to a Frame shift mutation?
Explanation: Explanation: If overall the two frame shift mutations lead to a change of 3 or its multiple in the genetic code, the codons will again be in the same frame. This is an internal compensation, so intragenic suppression.

Question: 13. Which sequences among these will have a preference for frame shift?
Explanation: Explanation: Repetitive sequences have a greater chance of frame shift mutation due to polymerase error. The polymerase tends to slide through these same sequences as even the base pairing is not much affected if it does so.

Question: 14. The normal form for A and C, and G and T are _____________
Explanation: Explanation: The normal form of A and C is amino and that of G and T base is Keto. Shift to imino and enol form is due to tautomeric shift, it is a rare phenomenon.

Question: 15. In an experiment your germ cell was having a base at its unusual tautomeric state while replication. What could be the maximum percentage of germ cells carrying this mutation?
Explanation: Explanation: It has been experimentally seen that a mutation can effect at max 50% of the progeny cells. This is due to the fact that there are two DNA strands and only one of them is carrying the mutation. So, only progenies receiving copies of that mutant strand will be mutant i.e. 50%.

Question: 1.  You are studying a mutational hot spot in the promoter region of a gene. Which type of mutation will you expect the most in this case?
Explanation: Explanation: Mutational hot spots are regions which are rich in 5MC and these on deamination give a T base. Under normal condition deamination of C gives a U which is spontaneously excised out, but as T is a normal DNA base the mutation is fixed.

Question: 2. 5 Bromo uracil can pair with _____________
Explanation: Explanation: This is a base analogue that is a pyrimidine. Under normal conditions it behaves like T and base pairs with A; but under abnormal conditions, it behaves as C and Base pair with G. As a pyrimidine canÕt base pair with another pyrimidine, G is the only available option.

Question: 3. Deamination of which of the bases which nitrous acid will not lead to any change in the base pairing?
Explanation: Explanation: Deamination of guanine will give Xanthine, which also base pairs with Cytosine. Thus the base pairing is not changed.

Question: 4. Which of the following agents can lead to both addition and deletion mutation?
Explanation: Explanation: Proflavin, like Ethidium bromide is an intercalating agent. This when inserted in DNA can lead to addition of a random base, and when lost can lead to deletion.

Question: 5. Which of the mutations can be detected Phenotypically?
Explanation: Explanation: All the other mutation lead to wild phenotype, so unless a genetic analysis is performed, they are indistinguishable. But in case of sense a stop codon is changed to a coding codon which has a serious phenotypic effect on the protein.

Question: 7. Which of the following mutation will lead to AT->GC transition?
Option A: a) Nitrous acid acting on A
Explanation: Explanation: All options other than oxidation of A by nitrous acid lead to GC->AT transition. Nitrous acid converts A to Hypoxanthine that in place of pairing with T pairs with C. Thus, it leads to AT->GC transition.

Question: 8.  In Ames test, the bacterial culture are grown in _________
Explanation: Explanation: Only prototroph can grow in minimal media. In the Ames test, the mutagenicity of a substance is tested by its ability to convert an auxotroph into a prototroph. Thus to check for mutants, the media must be minimal so that only mutant colonies grow.

Question: 9. In an experiment to check mutagenicity of a substance, we feed the mutagen to a rat and then use the rat _______ extract within the media. This ensures_____________
Option A: a) Kidney; the mutagen can be at a higher concentration
Option B: b) Liver; the media has adequate iron from rat RBC
Option C: c) Liver; the mutagen is processed
Option D: d) Kidney; the mutagen is broken down
Explanation: Explanation: Rat is a mammal similar to human being. In us the food undergoes several processing steps than it would in case of a simple prokaryote like bacteria. Thus, using a rat liver extract ensures that the functional state of the substance is in the extract ensuring more efficiency. Liver processed all the toxins so its extract is used.

Question: 10. Which of this mutagen can lead to both AT->GC and GC->AT transition?
Explanation: Explanation: 5 Bromo Uracil when incorporates in the DNA in a normal state and then undergoes transition to a rare state in the next replication cycle leads to an AT->GC mutation. While when it incorporates against a G in excited state and then undergoes replication when in the normal state it gives GC->AT transition.

Question: 1.  Which of the following modes of repair is restricted to S phase of the cell cycle?
Explanation: Explanation: MMR/mis-match repair system concerns the wrong bases incorporated by polymerase error while replication. It has to distinguish the parent and daughter strand for this repair. Since after replication completion and during division both the stands are indistinguishable, it is restricted to S phase.

Question: 2. DNA microsatellites are prone to which type of mutation?
Explanation: Explanation: DNA microsatellites have several repetitive sequences within it, thus these regions are prone to polymerase slippage that can lead to insertion or deletion of bases.

Question: 3. In an experiment you make two setups, in 1st you knock down the DAM and in 2nd you over express DAM. What will be the observation for both the setups?
Option A: a) In 1st case BER is compromised and in 2nd MMR is compromised
Option B: b) In 1st case MMR is compromised, while in 2nd MMR is more accurate
Option C: c) In both cases MMR is compromised
Option D: d) In both cased BER is compromised
Explanation: Explanation: DAM knockdown leads to no methylation, and then both strands are indistinguishable as both are not methylated. While in DAM over expression both are methylated at a shorter window giving lesser time for MMR to work. Thus, the MMR in either case is compromised.

Question: 4. Which of the following factors in MMR can recognize the mismatch?
Explanation: Explanation: Mut S is responsible for recognizing the mismatch and then it complexed with Mut L which helps it to bind to the nearest Mut H and carry out the repair process.

Question: 5. If the nick is at 5Õ end of the mismatch which of the following will be recruited?
Explanation: Explanation: Rec J is an exonuclease which is also known as exonuclease VII. It is responsible for chewing the DNA from 5Õ to 3Õ direction. While exonuclease I and X chew from 3Õ to 5Õ direction which will not be of much use in this case.

Question: 6. Which MMR protein homologue has not yet been discovered in eukaryotes?
Explanation: Explanation: While Mut S homologue (MSH) and Mut L homologue (MLH) has been discovered in eukaryotes, the Mut H homologue is not found. The nick in the lagging strand is expected to be provided by the unligated okazaki fragments.

Question: 7. Which of the following disease in humans is due to the error in MMR?
Explanation: Explanation: Lynch syndrome, also known as Hereditary Non-Poyposis Colon Cancer is due to the slippage of replicative machinery in the microsatellite region of the chromosomes where it encounters repetitive sequences. Option b and d are errors in NER.

Question: 8. Which of the following mismatches will be ignored by MMR?
Explanation: Explanation: It has been observed that although MMR can effectively detect and repair most of the mismatches like TÑT, AÑC, GÑT, AÑA  etc, it canÕt detect CÑC, this may be due to cÑC causing less distortion in the DNA.

Question: 9. Mut H acts as ______________
Explanation: Explanation: Mut H can bind to hemi-methylated DNA and make a nick in the strand with unmethylated GATC sequence. As it makes a nick within the DNA it is an endonuclease.

Question: 10. 6, 4 PP are brought about by which type of mutagen?
Explanation: Explanation: 6,4 Pyrimidine photoproducts are formed when the DNA is exposed to strong radiation like UV or X-rays. These can be repaired by BER.

Question: 1. Which of the following is not a function of APE1?
Option D: d) Improving fidelity of pol beta
Explanation: Explanation: While APE1 has a 5Õ-> 3Õ exonuclease activity, it is not a bifunctional glycosylase and canÕt generate an abasic site.

Question: 2. Which of the DNA polymerase in prokaryotes is responsible for re-synthesizing the stretch in MMR?
Explanation: Explanation: Polymerase III is responsible for re-synthesizing the stretch of DNA in MMR between the nick made my Mut H and the mis paired base.

Question: 4. Which DNA polymerase plays a role in repair synthesis in BER in prokaryotes?
Explanation: Explanation: While pol III is responsible for the repair synthesis in MMR, pol I is however responsible for repair synthesis in BER in prokaryotes.

Question: 5. BER detects wrong bases by __________________
Option A: a) Bulges produced in the DNA
Option B: b) Strength of bond between the bases
Option D: d) Detected by RNA polymerase stalling
Explanation: Explanation: It has been seen that mis-incorporated bases have a tendency to appear flipped out, these flipped out bases are recognized by the BER. This is because flipping requires less energy than distortions like bulging. RNA pol stalling can trigger NER mainly TC-NER.

Question: 6. AP endonuclease can cleave the DNA at__________ while AP lyase will cleave the DNA at__________
Explanation: Explanation: The AP endonuclease can cleave at the 5Õ end of the Apurinic or Apyrimidine site, while the bifunctional AP lyase cleaves at the 3Õ end.

Question: 7. Which of the following canÕt be repaired by BER?
Explanation: Explanation: BER usually deals with single base damages, and NER takes care of the damages involving bulky lesions like CPD. Abasic site generation is the 1st step of BER process so it can carry out the reaction easily.

Question: 8. Which of the bond in the nucleotide is broken 1st in BER?
Option A: a) Bond between two consequent bases
Option B: b) Bond between base and sugar
Option C: c) Bond between base and phosphate
Option D: d) Bond between two complementary bases
Explanation: Explanation: The glycosidic bond between the sugar residue and the nitrogenous base is the 1st to be broken by BER glycosylases generating an abasic site.

Question: 9. Which of the following will be seen to resolve the flap in eukaryotic short patch BER?
Explanation: Explanation: In eukaryotes, there is no requirement of a phosphodiesterase to resolve the short flap generated by short patch BER. It is taken care of by pol beta.

Question: 10. Which factor works in conjugation with FEN1?
Explanation: Explanation: PCNA or the beta clamp analogue in eukaryotes assists the FEN1 to cleave the long flap generated by long patch BER. This canÕt be taken care of by the pol beta alone.

Question: 1. In an experiment you fuse cells from two patients suffering from XP ( Xeroderma Pigmentosum). The fused cells will be expected to agree to which of the following?
Option A: a) The resultant cells will have worsened case of XP
Option B: b) Only one of the two NER defects that is dominant will be seen
Option C: c) No XP defect in the resultant
Option D: d) Both will show a similar effect of XP as before
Explanation: Explanation: As the disease Xeroderma pigmentosum is caused by different in different NER gene, such fusion will show complementation and the resultant phenotype will be normal.

Question: 2. The bulky lesions in GG-NER is detected by ___________
Explanation: Explanation: XPC in association with the hHR23B is responsible for recognizing the bulky lesions and attaching the XPB and XPD.

Question: 3. Which of the following NER factors is also a subunit of a transcription factor?
Explanation: Explanation: XPB and XPD are two subunits of the transcriptional factor TFIIH that acts as a helicase unwinding the region around the bulky lesion. It also marks the junctions of the ss and dsDNA where the cleavage would occur.

Question: 4. Which of the exonucleases of NER binds to which end of the lesion?
Option A: a) XPD on 3Õ end and XPB on 5Õ end
Option B: b) XPF on 3Õ end and XPA on 5Õ end
Option C: c) XPG on 3Õ end and XPF on 5Õ end
Option D: d) XPD on 3Õ end and XPA on 5Õ end
Explanation: Explanation: While XPD and XPB bind to the 3Õ and 5Õ end respectively, they are helicases and not exonucleases. On the other hand XPF along with ERCCI that binds to 5Õ end and XPG are exonucleases.

Question: 5. Which of the DNA polymerase in eukaryotes is responsible for repair synthesis of the excised strand in NER?
Explanation: Explanation: Major polymerase in eukaryotes is pol delta and pol epsilon. So, they are responsible of repair synthesis of the excised out patch in NER.

Question: 6. What is the stretch of free DNA needed by NER machinery to repair the bulky lesions in TC NER?
Explanation: Explanation: A stretch of free 100 nt is needed by NER machinery to excise out and replace the lesion. Thus, either the transcribing RNA polymerase then has to backtrack or it falls off.

Question: 7. Which of the factors are necessary in TC NER but not in GG NER?
Explanation: Explanation: The factors CSA and CSB help the RNA polymerase to backtrack when it encounters a lesion. However, hHR23B in association with XPC is more necessary in GG NER to detect the lesion.

Question: 8. Which of the factor in prokaryotic NER acts as the helicase?
Explanation: Explanation: Uvr D is the factor responsible unwinding the DNA in prokaryotes and excising the sequence with the lesion. On the other hand, TFIIH is also a helicase for eukaryotes.

Question: 9. Which of the molecule in photolyase acts as an electron donor for recovery of the CPD?
Explanation: Explanation: When the chromophore MTHF poly Glu receives the UV light, it passes the energy on to FADH- which in turn passes the electron to CPD. The electron helps in rearrangement of the bonds in CPD and returns them to the form of two pyrimidine residues.

Question: 10. You radiate a stock of E. Coli with UV rays and another stock is irradiated as control. The 1st stock is seen to be more resistant to alkylating agents. Which gene is expected to be triggered by this UV?
Explanation: Explanation: While Alk B is also a de-methylating agent, but in E. coli the UV inducible de-alkylating agent is 8-oxo guanine methyl transferase.

Question: 12. What is the molecule released in 2nd step of Alk B reaction which returns the base to normal form?
Explanation: Explanation: Alk B converts the methyl group to carbonyl group by oxidation, with the help of alpha ketoglutarate. The 1st step releases succinate while in the 2nd step the carbonyl group releases the formaldehyde.

Question: 13. What is the prokaryotic homologue of XPC?
Explanation: Explanation: In eukaryotes, XPC works in conjugation with hHR23B which is simply the human homologue of RAD 23. RAd 51 is involved in DSB repair.

Question: 1.  Homologous recombination canÕt occur in which stage?
Explanation: Explanation: For homologous recombination to take place there must be two sister chromatids with same or similar composition. This is available only after DNA replication, thus it canÕt take place in G1 phase before replication.

Question: 3. What is the role of Rec BCD in DSB repair?
Option A: a) It helps in strand invasion
Option B: b) It chews off the flap
Option C: c) It helps to generate 3Õ overhang
Option D: d) It helps by aligning the two homologous chromosomes
Explanation: Explanation: Rec BCD acts as an exonuclease that selectively chews off the 5Õ end of DNA to generate a 3Õ overhang. This is necessary for strand invasion by this 3Õ overhang which brings about recombination repair.

Question: 4. Rec BCD can chew 3Õ end of the DSB till it reaches _____________ sequence.
Explanation: Explanation: Initially the exonuclease Rec BCD can chew up both the 3Õ and 5Õ end of the DSB till it reaches the specific chi sequence in the 3Õ strand. Then it stops chewing the 3Õ end and increases its activity in the 5Õ end.

Question: 5. Which of the following will be a marker of DSB?
Explanation: Explanation: In DSB the canonical bases are replaced by the non-canonical bases, which it also phosphorylated by ATM kinase.  H2AX is one such non-cannonical base, while there is no H3BX or H5G. H2AX is phosphorylated at gamma not alpha.

Question: 6. Which of these is not a part of the tri protein complex in homologous DSB repair?
Explanation: Explanation: The MRN complex or the tri protein complex that can recognize the DSB consists of MRN11, NBS1 and RAD 50. Rad 51 is a eukaryotic homologue of Rec A which guides the strand to invade the other homologue.

Question: 7. What is the structure of Rec A filament?
Explanation: Explanation: Rec A factors join together to form right handed alpha helical structure around the single strand of DNA. This has 6.2 Rec A per turn.

Question: 8. Which of these factors is not responsible for the assembly of Rec A oh the DNA?
Explanation: Explanation: Rec B is a pard of Rec BCD complex that helps to generate the 3Õ overhang. On the other hand, Rec FOR complex is responsible for assembling Rec A on the DNA stand and guides its invasion.

Question: 9. Which of the following is not true about ATM kinase?
Option A: a) It is guided to the DSB site by MRN complex
Option B: b) It exits as inactive dimer
Option C: c) It is activated to monomer by another factor of DSB repair
Option D: d) It phosphorylates BRCA1 and BRCA2
Explanation: Explanation: ATM kinase is activated by autocatalysis. It however is a major kinase which phosphorylates the H2AX, BRCA 1 and 2, 53BP1 and many other factors in DSB repair.

Question: 10. In DSB repair in G1 phase, which of these factors would be seen which is absent in other phases?
Explanation: Explanation: In G1 phase we have non homologous end joining. In this phase Ku 80/90 hetero dimer senses are repairs the DSB in absence of a homologous chromosome. RAD 51 and MRN are also seen in homologous repair in S or G2 phase, and RAD 23 is needed for NER.

Question: 11. Which of the following is most flexible ligase?
Explanation: Explanation: Ligase IV has exceptional flexibility as it can even ligate dissimilar DNA ends. It can also ligate the overhand with a complex structure. This is necessary for the immediate repair of the NHEJ breaks.

Question: 12. Which of the following has both kinase and nuclease property?
Explanation: Explanation: Ku PKC has the property of both kinase as well as nuclease. Thus, it can work in non-homologous DSB without the help of additional nucleases.

Question: 13. Which of the following is not true about NHEJ?
Option A: a) In most of the cases, it is associated with loss of genetic material
Option B: b) Ku is present at a concentration as high as 400000 per cell
Option C: c) It strand invasion looks for micro-homology regions
Option D: d) The 3Õoverhang chewed up to chi sequence invades to search for homology
Explanation: Explanation: In NHEJ to reduce the loss of genetic information and for a quicker search of homology domains the 3Õ over hand is only 4 nt long. This increases the probability of fining micro homology region as well as prevents loss.

Question: 14. Which of the following is not a sensor of DSB?
Explanation: Explanation: P53 is associated with DSB as ATM kinase phosphorylates 53BP1 that on activation codes for P53. On the other hand P21 is not associated with DSB. Ku and H2AX the non-canonical base is also associated with DSB repair.

Question: 1.  Which factor in the resolve some drives branch migration?
Explanation: Explanation: The Ruv B binds to the DNA in Holliday intermediate to two branch points. This factor helps in branch migration.

Question: 2. Choose the endonuclease that can cuts double strand of DNA.
Explanation: Explanation: ECoRI is a restriction endonuclease that can cut both the DNA strands generating an overhand. On the other hand Ruv C in recombination repair, Mut H in MMR and S1 endonuclease can only make single strand nicks.

Question: 3. Which factor helps in generation of chicken foot Holliday intermediate?
Explanation: Explanation: Rec FOR is necessary for strand migration which causes the reverse fork migration during repair of bulky lesions in DNA.

Question: 4. Single stranded nicks can be repaired without any loss of genetic material by which of the following processes?
Explanation: Explanation: In recombinational repair with the help of Rec BCD using the complementary strand as a template, the ssDNA breaks can not only be bypassed but also repaired effectively.

Question: 5. How many Holliday branch points are produced during DSB repair?
Explanation: Explanation: In case of DSB there are two branch points produced. One where the 3Õ overhang invades the homologous strand and other when it hybridizes with the other 3Õ end.

Question: 6. Defect in which of these genes produce an increased propensity to breast cancer?
Explanation: Explanation: Defects in the genes of BRCA 1 and BRCA 2 increases the propensity of breast cancer to 80%.  On the other hand option a, b and d doesnÕt directly play a role in breast cancer.

Question: 7. You have two circular chromosomes that are undergoing homologous recombination. The resolution of Holliday intermediate will give rise to _________________
Option C: c) One larger circular chromosome or two smaller chromosomes
Explanation: Explanation: Resolution of Holliday intermediate will give rise to two smaller chromosomes if resolved in one way. And it can also give rise to one larger chromosome if it is resolved in the other way, but both of these have 50% chance and it doesnÕt occur together.

Question: 8. What is the base incorporated by pol eta against a DNA CPD lesion?
Explanation: Explanation: Cyclo butane pyrimidine dimers consist of two T bases joined to form a bulky lesion. Pol eta incorporates two random A base against it.

Question: 1.  Type I restriction endonuclease cuts________________
Option B: b) On either side of the recognition sequence
Option C: c) 25 to 30 bp away from the recognition sequence
Option D: d) 1000bp away from the recognition sequence
Explanation: Explanation: Type I restriction endonucleases are of very less practical utility, this is because although they recognize a particular sequence, they cut the DNA up to 1000bp away not providing much specificity.

Question: 2. Which of the following is not true for type 1 restriction endonuclease?
Option A: a) It is a single enzyme with 3 subunits
Option B: b) Using it is an energy requiring process
Option C: c) Methylation and cleavage occurs in the same sequence
Option D: d) The cleavage is up to 1000bp away
Explanation: Explanation: Type 1 restriction endonuclease recognizes and cleaves at different points. While it methylates at the recognition sequence, the cleavage could be as far as 1000bp. Also both these processes require ATP.

Question: 3. Which of the following is not true about type II restriction endonuclease?
Option A: a) Here Clevage and Methylation are by different enzymes
Option B: b) In this case the recognition sequence is asymmetric
Option C: c) It cleaves within the recognition sequence
Option D: d) It canÕt cleave at methylated sequences
Explanation: Explanation: In case of recognition sequence type IIs the recognition site in asymmetric. While in case of type II the recognition site is symmetric.

Question: 4. Restriction endonucleases can recognize___________
Explanation: Explanation: Restriction endonuclease will recognize the pallindromic sequences. GATC is one of such pallindromic sequence but not the only one, and this is very specific.

Question: 5. What does this sequence GC/GGCCGC recognized and cleaves by Not1 DoesnÕt agree to?
Option A: a) The cleavage is after the 2nd C from 5Õ end
Option B: b) The cleavage generates a 5Õ overhang
Option C: c) This sequence has a probability of occurrence in every 1024 bases
Explanation: Explanation: The probability of occurrence of an 8 bp recognition sequence can be determined as 48, this is because there are 4 bases and 8 specific bases in position in this sequence; which is equal to 65536. However the rest of the options are true.

Question: 6. Which of the sequence will Dcm methylate?
Explanation: Explanation: DCM methylates at the C base while DAM methylates at the A base. DCM methylates ta the internal C of the sequence CCAGG. The sequence CCGTT is not a palindrome and GATC is recognized and methylated by DAM.

Question: 7. In an experiment you introduce your gene of interest in a wild type E. cloli genome using an episome. However, you fail to see the product protein being formed. What could be the possible reason for this?
Option B: b) The gene product was produced in negligible quantity
Option C: c) The bacteria was in stress so it was not producing much protein
Option D: d) The gene was excised out
Explanation: Explanation: While all the reasons stand a possibility of being true, under the experimental condition it might be due to the restriction enzyme cleaving out GOI considering it a virus. Thus, the E. coli strains need to be restriction deficient but methylation proficient.

Question: 8.  Which of the following enzyme air is a neoisoschizomer?
Explanation: Explanation: Neo-isoschizomers are the enzymes that recognize the same sequence and cleave at different points. Here, both Sma1 and Xma1 recognize GGGCCC; the 1st cleaving after the 3rd G and 2nd cleaving after the 1st.

Question: 9. Which of these restriction enzymes generate 3Õ overhang?
Explanation: Explanation: Sph1 recognized the sequence AGTAC/G, as it cleaves near the 3Õ end of the sequence it generates an asymmetric cut with 3Õ overhang. While Sma1 produces a blunt end and Xma1 and EcoR1 produces a 5Õ overhang.

Question: 10. Restriction enzymes cleave the bond by which type of reaction?
Explanation: Explanation: The reaction is by hydrolysis of the phosphodiester bond between two sugar residues by a nucleophilic attack. Inverted product configuration shows that the substrate was inverted only once. As only bimolecular nucleophilic reaction causes only one time inversion so that is the correct option.

Question: 11. The Mg2+ ion in restriction endonuclease is not bound to ________
Option B: b) Carboxylates of the enzymes aspertate group
Explanation: Explanation: In restriction endonucleases we donÕt have His as a ligand to the central metal ion Mg2+. While itÕs binding to the other groups assists in the nucleophilic attack.

Question: 12. In EcoRV the enzyme is a ____________
Explanation: Explanation: As the enzyme recognizes the palindrome sequences, the homodimer would be able to recognize the same sequence from the other end. Thus, restriction endonucleases are homodimers.

Question: 13. When the DNA enzyme interacts with the cognate DNA, there is _______________
Explanation: Explanation: On restriction endonuclease binding to cognate DNA there is a reduction in free energy to a greater extent than that in case of non-cognate DNA. This additional energy is used to distort the sequence and produce a kink.

Question: 14. Methylated DNA doesnÕt form kink as________________
Option A: a) As they donÕt fit in the active site
Option B: b) The enzyme recognized methylated A as different base than non-methylated A
Option C: c) They are less flexible so no kink is formed
Option D: d) They donÕt interact with the side chains in an active site
Explanation: Explanation: The kink in the DNA is formed not by just the recognition of the base sequence in the restriction site, but also by the interactions of the side chains. Asp 185 is unable to interact with methylated A, so no kink is formed.

Question: 1.  In which of the following will you expect plasmids to be absent?
Explanation: Explanation: Among the following options only prokaryotes and lower eukaryotes like yeast can have plasmids. So option a and d being prokaryote and b being yeast has plasmid. But option c being higher eukaryote i.e. the genus of tiger lacks plasmids.

Question: 2.  Which of the following is not true about plasmids?
Option D: d) They may get incorporated in chromosome
Explanation: Explanation: Plasmids generally donÕt get incorporated in a chromosome; if it does so then it is known as episome not plasmids. It is true that plasmids are circular, double stranded, extrachromosomal DNA that can confer antibiotic resistance.

Question: 3. Which class of plasmids assists in the production of bacteriocins?
Explanation: Explanation: Col plasmids help in the production of cilicins and bacteriocins. This helps them to kill other bacteria. While F plasmids confer fertility and R confers resistance to some antibiotics.

Question: 4. Which of the following is not a part of RTF?
Explanation: Explanation: The R agent class of plasmids consists of Resistance transfer factor RTF as well as Resistance gene R. While the origin of replication and transfer, and pilli forming gene are part of RTF; antibiotic resistance gene such as Chloramphenicol resistance gene is part of R.

Question: 5. In an experiment you want to express your gene of interest in a prokaryote through a plasmid. What would be your ideal copy number?
Explanation: Explanation: The gene of interest by us should always be expressed in low copy number as if it is in higher copy number t will use more of bacterial recourses without helping them at all. So, bacteria might then dispense some of these chromosomes.

Question: 7. Which of the following antibiotic resistance is through alteration of uptake?
Explanation: Explanation: Tetracyclin resistance is provided by some transporters that selectively transport tetracycline outside the cell thus providing resistance; whereas the other antibiotics are through other modes of resistance.

Question: 8. Which of the following plasmids fir the definition of episomes?
Explanation: Explanation: Episomes are the plasmids that can get incorporated in a central chromosome. F factors or fertility factor is one such plasmid.

Question: 9.  Streptomycin resistance is conferred by______________
Explanation: Explanation: Streptomycin resistance is through the modification of the target i.e. Ribosome, so that it can no longer interact with streptomycin in the same way.

Question: 10. Bacteriocins are _______________
Explanation: Explanation: Bacterocins are ribosomally synthesized proteins or peptides that are not toxic to the producer but to the other bacteria around it.

Question: 11. Bacteriocins are produced by bacteria in __________
Explanation: Explanation: In the S phase there is a lot of competition between the bacterias for space and resources. Bacteriocins are used to kill off the bacterias of same species or related bacteria to resuce the competition.

Question: 12. What is the general target of bacteriocins?
Explanation: Explanation: Bacteriocins have proteolytic and amylolytic enzymes that can digest the cell wall and kill the bacteria. It generally doesnÕt target anything else.

Question: 1.  Conjugation canÕt take place between_________________
Explanation: Explanation: For conjugation to take place one bacterium must have the F plasmid and other should lack it. HFR has the components of F plasmid within its genome so it canÕt mate with another F+.

Question: 2. In an experiment you have met, bio, thr+ and leu + bacterial strain in test tube 1; and met+, bio+, thr and leu bacterial strain in other test tube 2. Which of the following will not comply with your experimental results?
Option A: a) Both the strains will grow in enriched media
Option B: b) 2nd strain will grow in met absent media
Option C: c) Mixture of two strains will grow in minimal media
Option D: d) 1st stain will not grow in leu absent media
Explanation: Explanation: In this case, the 1st strain will have the ability to make leu as it is leu+. So it can grow in leu+ media. The ability of the mixture to grow in minimal media is due to the fact that gene transfer has taken place.

Question: 3. In case of mixing his+ leu- strain with his- leu+ strain we can see that the auxotroph behaves as prototroph for these two genes. This is because of________________
Option A: a) One is synthesizing one amino acid and giving it to the other type
Option B: b) They fuse to form similar diploid bacteria
Option C: c) Both will have the same genetic composition at the end
Option D: d) They share the RNA by extracellular processes
Explanation: Explanation: Genetic transfer, mainly by conjugation will result in incorporation of the His+ Leu+ gene in both the strains at the end. Then they can produce both these amino acids by themselves and grow on minimal media. This is not by extracellular process but by contact.

Question: 4. Which gene in a plasmid is indispensible for it to participate in conjugation?
Explanation: Explanation: There is no particular sex determining gene in bacteria, their pseudo sex is determined by presence or absence f fertility factor. However pilli forming gene is necessary for the conjugation channel, ori of transfer and ori of replication also maintain a plasmid.

Question: 5. Which of the following can transfer the genes in bacterial nucleoid as well?
Explanation: Explanation: While FÕ can transfer one or two of the bacterial gene as well, but only HFR can transfer the gene from the nucleoid of the bacteria as it is the F plasmid incorporated in the central chromosome.

Question: 6. A HFR bacteria mates with an F- plasmid containing bacteria. What will be the type of bacteria after conjugation is complete?
Explanation: Explanation: In HFR rarely the complete chromosome can be transferred from one bacterium to other due to the continuous motion of the medium. Here only partially the genes from Ori of transfer till the point where conjugation channel is broken gets transferred. As the full F plasmid can thus never be transferred so it is F-.

Question: 8. In and interrupted mating experiment, it is seem that the after 10 mins AziR gene in recipient, after 20 minuites there is appearance of tonR  and after 15 mins the recipient is lac+ , but the recipient is almost never his+.  Where in the genome is the ori of transfer?
Option A: a) Between AziR and TonR genes
Explanation: Explanation: As the origin of transfer is between His+ and AziR the sequence follows AziR, ->TonR->Lac+->His+ or the reverse direction. Thus, longer time is required for His to enter and in most cases before that the conjugation tube breaks.

Question: 10. In an experiment of determining the order of gene in bacteria we use HFR which is gal+, Lac+, Ara+ and His+. If the recipient is negative for all these genes, and we selectively choose Gal + and get the pattern-
Explanation: Explanation: While the HFR could incorporate in different positions by selecting one gene we are setting a start site for checking. Now the gene order agrees with the percent incorporation as the farther genes have a lower probability of incorporation.

Question: 11. For complete HFR to enter the recipient, how much time should the two bacterial cells be in contact?
Explanation: Explanation: The two participating bacteria taking part in conjugation should actually stay connected by conjugation tube for 100 minutes for the entire chromosome i.e. HFR to get transferred. However, as they are constantly in motion such occurrence is rare.

Question: 1. In an experiment you have a U-Tube with two strains of bacteria in two arms. In one arm the bacteria are Gal+ and His-, in other the strain is Gal- and His+. If the two arms are joined by a membrane that doesnÕt allow bacterial cells to pass to opposite site what will you observe when you plate each arm bacterial strain on minimal media?
Option B: b) Some colonies seen in right arm
Option C: c) Some colonies seen in left arm
Option D: d) Some colonies seen in both arms
Explanation: Explanation: Here the transfer of gene is mainly due to transformation. Although the bacterial cells couldnÕt come in physical contact yet their nucleic acids could flow with the liquid to other arm and it can be incorporated by the bacterial cells in the other arm.

Question: 3. If the genes order in bacteria is His gal met. Which of the following genes have the least probability of getting incorporated alone?
Explanation: Explanation: Gal can be incorporated alone only by the event of double cross over. Double crossover at such short stretch is of least occurrence so the probability of it being incorporated alone is least.

Question: 4. Which of the following species has natural competence?
Explanation: Explanation: Only 1% of all the bacterial strains are naturally competent. One among these is Streptococcus pneumonia, which can take up the chromosomes from the medium without prior treatment.

Question: 5. Competence can be generated in some strains of non-competent bacteria by __________
Option B: b) By treating them with penicillin
Explanation: Explanation: Electroporation is a technique where a short pulse f electricity is used to induce artificial competence in some cells. Treating with chitinase or penicillin will severely affect the cell wall and the cells will die.

Question: 7. What is the minimum length of DNA fragment in exogenote required for incorporation of the gene in the endogenote?
Explanation: Explanation: Although very small fragments of DNA are taken up by the cell, a minimum of 500bp is necessary for recombinational machinery to act on, thus for incorporation.

Question: 8. If the probability of incorporation of a gene A from a bacterial cell that has lysed in the medium is a. And the probability of incorporation of another gene B from the same bacteria that has lysed is b. What is the probability of one recipient receiving both?
Explanation: Explanation: For both genes to be incorporated together we must multiply the probability of incorporation of either genes. Thus, the probability value overall decreases.

Question: 9. Probability of incorporation of a gene P is 0.2 and the probability of incorporation of another gene is 0.1. The probability of both being incorporated is seen experimentally to be equal to 0.1. What is our inference?
Option A: a) Both the genes are incorporated randomly
Option C: c) The bacteria has a preference for the two gene
Option D: d) It was just an artifact
Explanation: Explanation: The probability of incorporation of both should be theoretically 0.2X0.1= 0.02. But experimentally it is found to be 0.1 which is the same as that of 2nd gene. Thus these genes are completely linked i.e. whenever b is incorporated a is incorporated as well.

Question: 10. If co-incorporation probabilities are given as p,o 0.1; o,r 0.02 ; p,r 0.15. What is the gene order
Option D: d) CanÕt be determined due to insufficient data
Explanation: Explanation: This is because o and p have an appreciable degree of co-incorporation, as does r and p but o and r have much lower degree of co-incorporation. This shows that p must be at the middle of o and r.

Question: 1.  Which of the following viruses will be useful for transduction?
Explanation: Explanation: T phages mainly undergo lytic cell cycle, while lamda phages have lysogenic cell cycle. For transduction to occur, the viral genome must integrate within the nucleoid else it will never incorporate bacterial gene within itself. Thus, only lamda phage will be able to help in transduction.

Question: 2. What is the capacity of viral gene storage termed as?
Explanation: Explanation: The viral head has a specific capacity to load Nucleic acid. This capacity can be satisfied by only viral genome, a combination of viral and bacterial genome or only bacterial genome. This is called head full capacity.

Question: 3. In a transduction experiment where the recipient is Met-, Ala-, Gal- you observe a recombinant phenotype Met+, Gal+ in some strains and Gal+ Ala+ in some strains. But in none of the cases can you find Met+ Ala+. What is the sequence of the gene?
Explanation: Explanation: The recombinant genotype Met+ Ala+ will only result in the case when there is a double cross over such that the middle portion is exchanged twice. This is of least occurrence and is deterministic for the sequence.

Question: 4. You are checking the sequence of 3 genes using generalized transduction mapping. The recipient is Leu-,  AziS, Thr- while the donor is Leu+,  AziR, Thr +. If you select the Leu+ as marker,  AziR would be 50% while Thr+ would be 2%. If you select Thr+ as marker Leu+ would be 3% and AziR would be 0%. What is the sequence?
Explanation: Explanation: Genes Leu and Azi and genes Leu and Thr have a tendency to be incorporated together; this is as a result of their physical proximity. On the other hand Thr and azi hardy show such tendency so they must be farther apart. This results in the sequence with Leu in the middle.

Question: 5. Which of the following is not true for specialized transduction?
Option A: a) The lysogenic viruses can perform this
Option B: b) A variety of genes can be transformed in this case
Option C: c) The viral genome is then incorporated in the bacterial genome
Option D: d) It is seen in lamda phage like K12
Explanation: Explanation: Here the viral genome is actually incorporated in the bacterial genome at a particular site. The virus can transfer the gene surrounding its recombination site only. It is certainly through lusogenic cycle which is seen in lamda phages including K12.

Question: 6. The Phage is incorporated in the bacterial genome by _____________________
Explanation: Explanation: A viral genome is introduced in bacteria as a circular plasmid. It will be incorporated by a single cross over between the att site of virus and the att Lamda site of bacteria.

Question: 7. Which of these is correct according to transduction?
Option A: a) Specialized transduction is due to excision error
Option B: b) FÕ plasmid can act in specialized transduction
Option C: c) Only specialized transduction in virus can be used to cause genetic variations
Option D: d) Bacteriophage nucleic acid is dispensable for virulence
Explanation: Explanation: When the Lysigenic virus enters Lytic cycle its gene has to excise out of the bacterial genome. Imperfections in this excision can cause excision of a part of bacterial genome along with the circular viral genes. This results in specialized transduction.

Question: 8. If the bacterial DNA sequence is Leu Met Att Gal Bio, which of the genes can be transferred via specialized transduction?
Explanation: Explanation: Att site is merely necessary for incorporation of the virus. In specialized transduction the sites directly beside the attachment point of the virus can be mistakenly excised with the part of viral gene. Here this phenomenon will occur only in case of Met and Gal.

Question: 9. A specialized transducing virus attacks a healthy bacterial cell. What will be the virulence of the viruses produced by this bacterial cell after infection?
Option A: a) They will me more virulent than original one
Option B: b) They will be equally virulent as original one
Explanation: Explanation: This is because some part of the viral genome is compromised for this improper excision making it specialized transducing phage. Without the complete viral genome, the resultant viruses will not be able to express their infective activity.

Question: 10. In which of the following cases will the viral progeny generated retain their infection ability?
Option A: a) A generalized trasducing phage affects a normal cell
Option B: b) A specialized transducing phage affects a cell infected by same virus
Option C: c) A specialized transducing phage will attack a normal cell
Option D: d) A generalized transducing phage will affect a cell with a different viral infection
Explanation: Explanation: When the recipient is already infected by the same virus the complete genome of specialized tranducing phage is already present. This will produce normal infective virus as well as more specialized transducing infective viruses.

Question: 11. A specialized transducing phage attacking an infected cell with lysogenic stage of the same virus gives rise to________
Explanation: Explanation: Hft or High frequency transducing viruses has a greater tendency to produce specialized transducing phage by improper excision event as they are very unstable. HFR occurs by integration of F plasmid after conjugation.

Question: 12. The recombination study of phages is done using ____________
Explanation: Explanation: In Plaque assay bacterial culture is grown in a plate and then it is infected by the viruses. The plaque so formed by the viruses is studies to categorize the morphological features and study the recombination.

Question: 2. Linkage ________ as the distance between two genes ______________
Explanation: Explanation: As the distance between the two gens increase, the probability of recombination event occurring between then is higher. Thus, linkage increases as the distance between two genes decrease and vice-versa.

Question: 3. In Drosophila males there is complete linkage. What is the reason behind this?
Option A: a) The genes are very closely located
Explanation: Explanation: In Drosophila male these is no formation of synaptonemal complex, hence no synapsis is the pachytene phase of meiosis I. As there is no synapsis, there is no recombination.

Question: 4. Linkage results in __________
Option A: a) Formation of more Dominant phenotype
Option B: b) Formation of more Wild phenotype
Option C: c) Formation of more parental phenotype
Option D: d) Formation of more recombinant phenotype
Explanation: Explanation: Linkage prevents recombination, thus it results in the formation of more parental phenotypes and lesser wild phenotypes. But it is not determining dominant/recessive traits or wild/mutant trait as that depends on genetic constitution of the parent.

Question: 5. If you suddenly observe linkage between two genes that are present in two chromosomes, this can be due to __________________
Explanation: Explanation: Translocation of a gene from one chromosome to another within the same genome will result in then being on same chromosome. Then they can show linkage relationship.

Question: 6. Accurate mapping of genes can be done using _______
Explanation: Explanation: When the distance between two genes is quite large there is increases possibility of double recombination event occurring between them. This can be avoided by 3 point mapping.

Question: 7. Recombination occurs in _________
Explanation: Explanation: The only possibilities in this case are recombination in 2 strands and 4 strand stage. The study of recombinants show that recombination at 2 stand stage will produce effectively the same combination as in the absence of recombination. Thus it must be in the 4 strand stage.

Question: 8. Double crossovers can involve two, three or four strands at a time. What will be the resultant percentage of recombined genes to normal genes in between which recombination occurred, taking all three types in consideration?
Explanation: Explanation: Taking all types of a double cross over in consideration only 50% of the resultant will show recombination between the genes which are located on two sides of these recombination events.

Question: 9. You cross a p+/v+ p+/v+ male drosophila to a p-/v- p-/v- and obtain the F1 hybrid. Now you cross the F1 male with double recessive female. What will be the recombination phenotype in F2?
Option B: b) p+/v+ p-/v- and p-/v- p-/v-
Option C: c) p+/v+ p-/v- and p-/v- p-/v- also p+/v- p-/v- and p-/v- p-/v-
Option D: d) p+/v+ p-/v- and p-/v- p-/v- also p-/v+ p-/v- and p-/v- p-/v-
