Explanation: Explanation: In heterozygous female the pairing is due to looping and then recombination in pericentric region can produce abnormal chromosomes which donÕt separate properly in anaphase. Thus, it prevents recombination in heterozygous females.

Question: 4. What are the results of pericentric inversion with single crossing over?
Option A: a) Two normal, one dicentric and one acentric chromosome
Option C: c) Four normal chromosomes with centriomere in different positions
Option D: d) 3 normal chromosome, one abnormal acentric chromosome
Explanation: Explanation: Recombination in the paracentric region will take place between only two strands, so the other two strands will be normal. This recombination will result in one dicentric chromosome and another acentric chromosome.

Question: 6. Long pericentric inversions generally donÕt act as cross over suppressors. Why?
Option A: a) Long stretches of DNA recombination not recognized
Option B: b) Mechanism is different for short and long inversions
Option C: c) Two events of crossing over take place
Option D: d) Cross over product in this is viable
Explanation: Explanation: Longer stretches of inversion favour formation of Double Crossover, then the DNA are resolved normally between all 4 meiotic products and no dicentric chromosome is formed. Thus, Long pericentric inversion generally donÕt act as cross over suppressors.

Question: 7. Choose the wrong option.
Option A: a) Paracentric inversion cross over products is non-viable
Option B: b) Pacentric non-cross over gametes segregates normally
Option C: c) Double cross over in paracentric inversion is lethal
Option D: d) There is genetic imbalance in gametes produced by paracentric inversion cross over
Explanation: Explanation: In paracentric inversion there is chromosomal imbalance in products of single cross over, but double cross over products lead to normal gene balance and viable gametes.

Question: 8. In drosophila male there is no cross over suppression due to pericentric inversion as___________
Option A: a) They have only one set of chromosome
Option B: b) They always have double cross over
Explanation: Explanation: Drosophila males donÕt recombine due to the absence of synaptonemal complex formation. Thus there is no question of recombination for it to be suppressed.

Question: 9. Which of the following is an example of inversion?
Explanation: Explanation: In chromosome 3 of human there is duplication-deletion which leads to inversion. The rest of the options give examples of genes participating in translocation.

Question: 10. In pericentric inversion, the inversion loop involves __________ strands.
Explanation: Explanation: In pericentric inversion there will be 4 strands in the inversion loop although only 2 will undergo recombination to give the recombination products. This is because the sister chromatids are bound by the centromere.

Question: 1.  Which of the following case of duplication involves more than one chromosome?
Explanation: Explanation: In transposed the segment could be passed to another homologous chromosome or extra chromosome with a centromere. However, tandem, revere tandem and displaced occurs within the same chromosome.

Question: 2. Tandem duplication creates ____________  and reverse tandem creates_____________
Explanation: Explanation: In case of tandem repeat the same sequence in same order is repeated. As parent chromosome has only one copy of that sequence the daughter bulges out. This, causes buckling. In reverse tandem the duplication is inverted in sequence which leads to formation of hairpin.

Question: 3. The StreisingerÕs model explains__________
Explanation: Explanation: StreisingerÕs model explains that the Frame shift mutations are more frequent in repetitive sequences. This causes duplicative insertion and also at times deletion.

Question: 4. If there are two sequences CGCGCGCG and ATATATAT, which will have a higher probability of being duplicated?
Option C: c) Both will have equal probability
Option D: d) Both are unlikely to be duplicated
Explanation: Explanation: Streisinger model works on repeated sequences, it is not base specific. In this case both the AT rich and CG rich sequences should have an equal probability of getting duplicated.

Question: 5. Which of the following will have the highest number of eye facete?
Explanation: Explanation: The bar gene is present in the X chromosome, thus, males canÕt have two copies for being homozygous or heterozygous. Ultra bar condition is most severe, then is the homozygous bar and then follows bar.

Question: 6. Duplication of Vermillion eye colour gene leads to the expression of the mutant phenotype. Which of the following can lead to normal phenotype with this duplication present?
Option B: b) Duplication of normal eye colour gene
Option C: c) Deletion of both the Vermillion gene
Option D: d) Translocation of Vermillion gene to another chromosome
Explanation: Explanation: Duplication in normal eye colour gene would balance the mutant gene product and lead to expression of wild type phenotype. Reverse tandem duplication will only create more copies of mutant making phenotype worse, also deletion of both genes will cause imbalance. Translocation makes no difference in expression unless itÕs beside a heterochromatin.

Question: 7. Which human chromosomes are involved in DownÕs syndrome?
Explanation: Explanation: In DownÕs syndrome a part of the 21st chromosomeÕs long arm duplicates and transfers to chromosome 14Õs long arm.

Question: 8. Which of the following could be due to duplication?
Explanation: Explanation: In case of Pleiotropy one gene effects several character; this may be due to mutations of the initial duplicated sequences.

Question: 9. If a gene undergoes duplication and one of the duplicated copy is mutated to render unexpressed protein. What will be the effect on phenotype?
Option C: c) Expression of the mutant gene is less than that would occur if both copy active
Option D: d) The gene not expressed at all
Explanation: Explanation: In this case as the product of the 2nd copy is mutated and not affecting the phenotype, only one copy is producing the required product in normal quantity. This is similar to the duplication being silenced.

Question: 10. During StrisingerÕs model, what happens?
Option A: a) The Ribosome slips which causes duplication
Option D: d) The polymerase back tracks and resynthesizes
Explanation: Explanation: Daughter strand slippage will cause looping which is stabilized by repetitive sequences. This leads to an increase in a number of repeats in the daughter.

Question: 2. How will you recognize a terminal deletion from breakage and loss at the terminal end?
Option B: b) Terminal break will lead to shorter chromosome than that due to chunk deletion
Option C: c) Terminal break will be sticky
Option D: d) Deletion will be recognized by trans factors
Explanation: Explanation: In terminal deletions the telomere is present; it is sort of removing the bases before telomere not including it. Terminal breaks will however lack telomerase and will be sticky. Shortening in both cases could be similar.

Question: 3. What will be the effect of the deletion mutation of a gene at the telomere?
Option B: b) Organism will develop serious hazards due to absence of the gene and its product
Option C: c) Mild effect on the phenotype
Explanation: Explanation: The genes at the telomere are silenced, and never expressed. It is in form of heterochromatin inaccessible to the transcription machinery. Thus, deletion of a gene that wasnÕt expressed to start with doesnÕt make much difference.

Question: 4. You hybridize two cells one of which carries a deletion mutation on chromosome 1. What will you expect to observe?
Option A: a) Buckling of chromatin of 1st cell
Option B: b) Buckling of chromatin of 2nd cell
Option C: c) Twisting and loop formation between the two chromatins
Explanation: Explanation: As chromosome 1 of 1st cell carries the deletion it will have less genes than that of the counterpart on the 2nd cell. There will be an error in a pairing where the extra part of 2nd cell chromatin corresponding to the deleted gene will buckle.

Question: 5. Which of the following is not a possible cause of lethality of individuals carrying a deletion mutation?
Option A: a) Genes that are not haplo sufficient doesnÕt produce adequate gene product
Option C: c) Unmasking of lethal recessive alleles
Explanation: Explanation: With the other reasons being true, lack of diversity affects at population level not at individual level. It is no cause for lethality of individuals with deleterious mutation.

Question: 6. The appearance of a recessive phenotype due to deletion of dominant gene is called_______________
Explanation: Explanation: Pseudo dominance is the condition when the recessive allele is expressed in deletion mutation of dominant. Hemi-dominance is the condition when only one copy of the gene is supposed to be present, as in genes of Y chromosomes. Co-dominance and imperfect dominance are different.

Question: 7. You generate a fluorescent probe against a gene that has been deleted. You expose the DNA to the probe and observe it under fluorescent microscope. What will you see?
Option A: a) Fluorescence will correspond to the gene of interest
Option B: b) There will be a number of regions that emit fluorescence
Option C: c) Most parts of the chromosome emits fluorescence
Option D: d) Nothing is seen under fluorescence microscope
Explanation: Explanation: The gene corresponding to the probe labeled with fluorescence is deleted. Thus, probe canÕt bind the DNA. In this case no fluorescence should be seen on the chromosome.

Question: 9. Deletion of a region led to over expression of a gene X. What do you conclude from this observation?
Option A: a) Part of gene X is mutated
Option B: b) Promoter of gene X is deleted
Option C: c) Regulator of gene X is deleted
Option D: d) No effect on gene X or its regulators
Explanation: Explanation: In this case over expression of gene X is due to deletion of some negative regulator like operon, insulator, silencer etc.

Question: 10. Yellow colour of mouse is generated by _________ mutation.
Explanation: Explanation: Here the agouti allele which is to be expressed only in certain tissues is brought under the control of Rally gene promoter which is expressed in all tissues, by deletion of Rally gene and agouti promoter in between the two. The strong promoter over expresses Agouty gene leading to the color.

Question: 11. Which of the following is not true about the Notch gene in Drosophila?
Option A: a) It causes a special indentation of the wing margin
Option B: b) It is expressed in heterozygous form
Option C: c) Notch is lethal in homozygous form
Option D: d) Notch is recessive to Facet
Explanation: Explanation: Facet is expressed only in absence of Notch gene by deletion, thus it is pseudo dominant and recessive to the notch gene. Other options are true, notch is also lethal in hemizygous condition.

Question: 1.  Euploidy is a chromosomal variation in ______________________
Explanation: Explanation: Euploidy is chromosomal variation in number which shows increase or decrease in complete set of chromosome number.

Question: 3. A male ant is _______________
Explanation: Explanation: Male ants, bees and wasps are produced by parthenogenesis, thus they have only one set of genes that was present in their mother- being monoploid.

Question: 4. A male bee canÕt have a________________
Explanation: Explanation: A male bee is produced from the unfertilized eggs by parthenogenesis, thus it will have a mother but not a father. The female mother was produced by fertilization so there is a grandfather and grandmother.

Question: 5. Which of the following will be sterile?
Explanation: Explanation: Tiploids are inherently sterile; this is due to the problem in meiosis that can produce a diploid and uniploid. The unpaired chromosome gets distributed in the two poles randomly leading to chromosomal inequality.

Question: 6. Colchicine is used to cause______________
Explanation: Explanation: Colchinine causes an arrest in anaphase which leads to mitotic non-disjunction halting the mitosis. This leads to doubling of chromosome as the duplicated chromatins fail to separate.

Question: 7. In an experiment, you culture the anthers and leaves of a flower. You see the plants so generated are_____________
Explanation: Explanation: Anthers are the meiosis products, so the plant generated from it is monoploid. Leaf is a normal diploid somatic tissue which will give to diploid individual.

Question: 8. Choose the odd one out?
Explanation: Explanation: Making a distinction on the basis of a number of sets of chromosome- endosperm is triploid while the rest are diploid.

Question: 9. Which of the following pairing will not occur during meiosis of tetraploid?
Option B: b) One bivalent and two univalent
Explanation: Explanation: In normal pairing all available chromosomes with complimentary are paired, so the existence of two univalent which are free to pair is not possible. However in case of trivalent and univalent as one of the other set is not available univalent exists.

Question: 10. Normal wheat Triticum aestivum is ___________
Explanation: Explanation: Triticum aestivum is hexaploid i.e. there are 6 set of chromosomes in it. This fertile as the segregation in divalent is possible.

Question: 11. Farmers often practice polyploidy as ____________________
Option A: a) It makes the plants more durable
Option B: b) They take longer time to undergo meiosis
Option C: c) It increases complexity and there is a hope of new species
Option D: d) It produces larger plant parts and products
Explanation: Explanation: In case of polyploid, more is the number of chromosome set more is the amount of gene product. As a result the plant will be larger is size which is a commercial profit.

Question: 12. In animals polypoidy is rarely practiced as _______________
Option A: a) Giants are harder to train and take care of
Option B: b) Increase in size is not appreciable
Option D: d) Animal cells are resistant to colchicine
Explanation: Explanation: The other options being true, in animals there is a more strict regulation of gene product formation than in the case of plants. In animals with an increase in cell size there would be a decrease in cell number keeping the ultimate animal sizes same. It is thus not profitable at all.

Question: 2. If an organism has 14 chromosomes, the number of chromosome generated by nullisomy will be_____________________
Explanation: Explanation: Nullisomy results in (2n-2) set of chromosome, here n=7, so it will result in 12 chromosome over all.

Question: 3. TurnerÕs syndrome is a result of _________________
Explanation: Explanation: In TurnerÕs syndrome one set of sex chromosmome is lost resulting in 44+XO females who have masculine condition. This is a result of monosomy.

Question: 4. Aneuploidy is usually deleterious as _________________
Option C: c) Size of individual may vary
Explanation: Explanation: In case of aneuploidy there is loss or gain in single chromosome which results in dis-balance of the genes and their products. This is a reason that aneuploids are usually lethal.

Question: 5. Which of the following is an example of trisomy ________________
Explanation: Explanation: Klinefelter syndrome results from trisomy in sex chromosome producing 44+ XXY. Turner is due to monosomy, endosperm is triploid i.e. the complete set of chromosome is increased and XP is due to mutation or deletion in gene not entire chromosome.

Question: 6. ________________ aneuploidy is better tolerated.
Explanation: Explanation: In case of sex chromosome due to dosage compensation in female one of X chromosome is inactivated. This is similar to the absence of a sex chromosome, which makes sex chromosome aneuploidy less lethal.

Question: 7. Patau syndrome is a result of which of the following?
Option A: a) Non-disjunction of sex chromosome in female
Option B: b) Non- disjunction of sex chromosome in male
Explanation: Explanation: Non-disjunction of chromosome 13 will result in a trisomy and monosomy if the gamete is fertilized. This results in Pataeu syndrome. It is an autosomal aneuploidy.

Question: 8. The probability of aneuploidy in offspring increases with age as _________________
Option A: a) Chromosomes tend to lose information with age
Option B: b) Pairings at dichtyotene stages are gradually lost
Option C: c) Ability of fertilization with age is gradually lost
Explanation: Explanation: The chromosomes with age tend to lose the proper pairings that existed when they were in dictyotene stage as this is prolonged over decades. This leads to improper segregation causing trisomy.

Question: 9.  A non-disjunction in the 1st phase of meiosis will lead to ______________
Explanation: Explanation: Nullysomy in chromosome is a loss of 2 chromosomes i.e. loss of a chromosomal pair. This can result from passing of both homologous chromosomes to the same pole during meiosis 1- this pole will produce trisomic gametes while the counterpart will produce nullisomic gametes.

Question: 10. At what maternal age the probability of having a child with DownÕs syndrome is increased drastically?
Explanation: Explanation: After the age of 35 the probability of non-disjunction in gamete leading to DownÕs syndrome increases to 1/290. With increasing age it increases still further.

Question: 11. Chromosome ____________ trisomy leads to EdwardÕs syndrome.
Explanation: Explanation: Chromosome 18 trisomy will lead to EdwardÕs syndrome. Trisomy in chromosome 13 and 21 leads to Patau and DownÕs syndrome respectively.

Question: 12. Sexual mosaics lead to formation of _______________
Explanation: Explanation: In case of sexual mosaics there is loss in one of the sex chromosomes in some cells. In case of male there will thus be a mosaic of male and female parts corresponding to XY and XO depending on which part has which combination.

Question: 13. Extreme klinefelter is an example of _____________________
Explanation: Explanation: In extreme klinefelter the chromosomal constitution is 44+XXXY, there are two extra X chromosomes which leads to more severe Klinefelter condition. Thus, it is tetrasomy.

Question: 14. Choose the wrong statement.
Option A: a) Maternal trisomy in a gamete is more severe in paternal gamete trisomy
Option B: b) Tetrasomy and nullisomy are due to change in chromosome number by 2
Option D: d) EdwardÕs syndrome is due to trisomy of chromosome 18
Explanation: Explanation: Disomy is nothing other than the normal chromosome numbers; this is having no harmful effect. The option a, b and d are however true.

Question: 1.  In cells the DNA replication takes place in _____________ phase.
Explanation: Explanation: In cells the DNA is replicated in the S phase. In G1 and G2 phase mainly the proteins required for mitosis is increased in quantity.

Question: 2. The cells before permanently differentiating enters into ______________ phase.
Explanation: Explanation: Before permanent differentiation the cells enter into G0 phase where they donÕt continue with the cell cycle. This immediately follows G1 phase.

Question: 3. Eggs in female stay in ______________ phase for extended duration.
Explanation: Explanation: Eggs are stored for long in the ovary in the diplotene stage of meiosis 1 known as dichtyotene. Then the chromosomes are paired according to the homologous pairing.

Question: 4. Which of the following will prevent cell cycle from progressing in case of DNA damage?
Explanation: Explanation: In case of DNA damage P53 senses the damage in DNA and blocks the further progression of the cell cycle unless the damage is repaired. This can even lead to apoptosis if the damage stays as it is.

Question: 5. In an experiment you increase the concentration of Cln3. What will be its effect on proliferating yeast cells?
Option A: a) Cells will be smaller in size
Option B: b) Cells will still have normal size
Option C: c) Cells will increase in size
Explanation: Explanation: Cln3 in yeast induces replication. If replication is more than cell growth, it will lead to gradual decrease in cell size.

Question: 6. Which of the following true about Rb in the cell cycle?
Option A: a) Phosphorylation of Rb will lead to its inactivation
Option B: b) Phosphorylation of Rb will also lead to inactivation of E2F
Option C: c) Phosphorylation of E2F will promote cell cycle progression
Option D: d) E2F is directly affected by Rb
Explanation: Explanation: Rb binds E2F and prevents cell cycle progression. If Rb is phosphorylated it will lead to release of E2F leading to continuation of the cell cycle.

Question: 7. The concentration of which of the following varies during the cell cycle?
Explanation: Explanation: The concentration of cyclin changes in a cyclic way during the cell cycle leading to various events; this regulates the phosphorylation and activation of the remaining participants bringing about cell cycle.

Question: 8. Which of the following is an activation process?
Explanation: Explanation: Cdc25 is a phosphatase that removes the inhibitory phosphate of the Cyclin-Cdk that prevents its activity- Thus, it activates Cyclin-Cdk. Other processes are inhibitory.

Question: 9. We know that caffeine helps to overcome M-Cdk activation checkpoint. What will be the fate of the cell treated with hydroxyl urea and caffeine in G1 phase?
Option B: b) Cell will become smaller in size
Option C: c) Cell will divide with improper chromosome number
Explanation: Explanation: Hydroxyurea prevents DNA replication. When this is coupled with caffeine that helps overcome M-Cdk checkpoint it leads to improper chromosome distribution among the daughter cells.

Question: 10. P53 requires ________________for its activity.
Explanation: Explanation: P53 prevents cell cycle progression during DNA damage. This is mediated with the help of Mdm which helps it to induce transcription of p21 that helps prevent a continuation of cell cycle.

Question: 11. The inactivation of M-Cdk is through the Cdc20-APC activity, what activates Cdc-20-APC?
Explanation: Explanation: M-Cdk itself promotes the ubiquitine lygase that marks M-cyclin for destruction, thereby inactivating M-Cdk. This helps in anaphase.

Question: 12. What is a negative regulator of Cdc-20?
Explanation: Explanation: Mad 2 bind to unbound kinetochores, which leads to inactivation of Cdc-20. This is a checkpoint that makes sure anaphase only occurs when all the centromeres are bound to spindle. M-Cdk and hct1 promote activity, while Mdm is not directly linked to its activity.

Question: 1. Mitosis occurs in _________
Explanation: Explanation: Mitosis occurs in proliferative somatic cells. This doesnÕt occur in ovary where oogenesis is via meiosis, and nephron and neurons donÕt proliferate. Mitosis occurs in a hair follicle.

Question: 2. Anaphase is brought about by the change in which cytoskeletal element?
Explanation: Explanation: Tubulin is the subunit of the microtubules that form the spindle fibres that help separate the chromatids.

Question: 3. Which of the following doesnÕt take place in prophase if mitotic cell?
Option B: b) The nuclear membrane breaks down
Option D: d) The chromosomes pair up with their homologue
Explanation: Explanation: Chromosomal pairing is a characteristic of meiotic cell not mitotic cell. Most of the steps in prophase of meiosis and mitosis being the same we observe the rest of the steps in mitotic prophase.

Question: 4. If you use colchicines, which of the cell division phases is prevented?
Explanation: Explanation: Colchicine disrupts the microtubule structure which leads to the absence of anaphase. While DNA replication is not prevented, so colchicines can effectively lead to chromosomal doubling.

Question: 5. If your chromosome is submetacentric, what will be the anaphase shape while separation?
Explanation: Explanation: During anaphase separation the chromatins are under a force, they tend to form  L shaped structure if they are metacentraic. I, J and V structures are formed by telocentric, acrocentric and metacentric chromosomes respectively.

Question: 6. Cdc20___________________ anaphase.
Explanation: Explanation: Cdc20 is a cell cycle component that promotes anaphase by decreasing the M-Cdk level and also leading to breakdown to cohesion.

Question: 7. Which one of the following doesnÕt help in degrading cohesion?
Explanation: Explanation: Securin binds to separase unless itÕs broken down by Cdc20. This separase breaks down cohesion. The degradation of cohesion is also assisted by M-Cdk as it activates Cdc20. So, among these only securing prevents Cohesin degradation.

Question: 8. If a permanent cell re enters cell cycle it is ______________
Explanation: Explanation: While differenciation is the process by which a mitotic cell becomes permanent, dedifferenciation is the reverse. On the other hand re-differenciation is the differenciation of the de-diffenenciated cell.

Question: 9. _________________ follows __________________
Explanation: Explanation: Karyokinesis is the diffusion of the nuclear materials which takes place before the cytoplasmic separation. Thus, cytokinesis follows karyokinesis.

Question: 11. Chromosomal compaction is brought about by  ________
Explanation: Explanation: The condensing molecule has two parts where each bind to two coils of a chromosome and bring them close. This results in chromosome compaction. Cohesin brings two chromosomes together during synapsis.

Question: 2. In haploid organism meiosis takes place in _____________
Explanation: Explanation: In haploid organisms the zygote is diploid which undergoes meiosis to give a haploid individual. Here, egg and other gamete are haploid as is somatic cell, so no meiosis is required by it.

Question: 3. The reduction division of mitosis is _________________
Explanation: Explanation: In the 1st division the chromosome number is reduced to half as the homologous pair separates to opposite pole. On the other hand in 2nd division the number of chromosome is constant just the chromatids separate like normal mitosis.

Question: 4. Which of the following is true for pre-leptotene phase?
Option C: c) Marked increase in nuclear volume
Explanation: Explanation: There is a marked increase in nuclear volume in pre-leptotene. Then the chromosomes are thin and randomly disperses, it is the preparatory stage for a cell to enter meiosis.

Question: 5. The leptotene Bouquet stage is seen in ______________
Explanation: Explanation: In animals and especially in insects in leptotene stage the chromosomes have their ends drawn to a point forming a bouquet structure. This is near the centriol. As plants lack centriol it is not seen in plants.

Question: 7. Which of the following is not true for leptotene phase?
Option A: a) It is a short phase
Option B: b) Chromosomes have beads on a string appearance
Option C: c) Longitudinal double nature of chromosome starts to appear
Option D: d) Bouquet like structure is formed
Explanation: Explanation: In leptotene phase the chromosomes have bead on string appearance with the chromatin fiber arranged like lateral loops on axis. But the bivalent nature is not yet visible at that time.

Question: 8. During leptotene there are ___________polyribosomes and ___________ ER vesicles in cytoplasm.
Explanation: Explanation: During the leptotene phase as the polyribosomes are synthesized, there are many polyribosomes ready for transcription. But there are only a few ER vesicles.

Question: 9. Choose the wrong statement out.
Option A: a) The leptotene chromosomes are arranged around an axis
Option C: c) The unbranched loops are lateral
Option D: d) Lateral filaments composed of two independent protein fibrils, one for each chromatid.
Explanation: Explanation: The chromosomal loops are often branches in lateral disposition. While it is true that they are arranged in loops around the axis and have protein fibrils.

Question: 10. Which of the following is directly correlated to polyribosomal synthesis in leptotene stage?
Explanation: Explanation: The rate of protein production and its turnover rate may be related to polyribosomes but the function of a protein is specific to the protein itself. Protein function is not directly affected.

Question: 1.  Which of the following will you expect to see in zygotene stage?
Option C: c) Bead on a string model
Explanation: Explanation: The zygotene chromosomes are more condensed than that in leptotene stage. The ball and seen mainly in leptotene stage while the O shaped structure is in diplotene. The thin chromatins are seen in interphase or pre-leptptene.

Question: 2. Which of the following events is seen in zygotene phase?
Explanation: Explanation: The main process taking place in zygotene is synapsis i.e. lengthwise pairing of homologous chromosome. Recombination follows this pairing and occurs in the pachytene stage.

Question: 3. If the pairing starts at terminal and proceeds towards centre it is known as ________________
Explanation: Explanation: In pro-terminal lengthwise pairing the pairing begins at the terminal and then it proceeds towards the centre. The reverse case is known as procentric.

Question: 4. If there is an improper attachment of spindle fiber, which protein sends the negative signal?
Explanation: Explanation: Mad2 is responsible for signalling improper binding of the spindle fiber to the centromere. This negative signal prevents apoptosis. Mdm2 is linked to p53 while Mcm activates ORC. Mek is a part of monomeric G protein signaling.

Question: 6. Which of the pairing is not feasible?
Option B: b) Pairing between homologous parts of non-homologous chromosome
Option C: c) Pairing between 4 chromosomes following translocation
Option D: d) Pairing between more than 2 chromosomes
Explanation: Explanation: Translocation may result in the chromosome that is partially homologous to two different chromosomes, this result in pairing of 4 chromosomes. Also homologous segments in non-homologous chromosomes can par. But pairing with more than 2 chromosomes in a normal instance is not seen.

Question: 7. Which of the following will not be seen in zygotene?
Explanation: Explanation: Unlike mitosis in meiosis there is both DNA synthesis and histone synthesis for protein compaction in meiosis stage. However, equatorial positioning is seen in metaphase only.

Question: 8. What is the percentage of DNA synthesized during zygotene?
Explanation: Explanation: Very less amount of DNA is replicated during zygotene while most are replicated in S phase. This unreplicated in DNA in chromosomes helps to hold the chromosomes together after zygotene.

Question: 9. What is the size of DNA that is left to be replicated in zygotene?
Explanation: Explanation: The amount of DNA left unreplicated is very less about 104 bp. Proper replication of this ensures zygotene progression.

Question: 11. The formation of synaptonemal complex is ______________ DNA replication in zygotene.
Explanation: Explanation: The replication of DNA in zygotene is mandatory for a synaptonemal complex formation to occur. These regions are also the first to get paired.

Question: 12. Which of the following is true?
Option A: a) Zygotene is the phase preceding diplotene
Option B: b) DNA replicated in zygotene is incorporated in chromosome 5-6 days later
Option C: c) Synaptonemal complex formed is longer than the physical length of chromosomes itself
Option D: d) The pairing of chromosomes forces the DNA to replicate
Explanation: Explanation: DNA replicated in zygotene phase is not immediately incorporated in the chromosome but it takes 5-6 days. While zygotene is followed by pachytene and the synaptonemal complex is shorter than the chromosome itself. The pairing follows replication and not vice versa.

Question: 1.  Which of the following doesnÕt lead to pairing in meiosis?
Option A: a) 0.3% DNA replication that was left after S phase
Explanation: Explanation: There is no turbulence factor leading to pairing in prophase, however it is true that the un-replicated DNA helps in pairing. Also precocity theory and retardation theory comes into play.

Question: 3. What is the size of each fiber of the synaptonemal complex?
Explanation: Explanation: The 10 nm fibers of synaptonemal complex are responsible for the pairing of homologous chromosomes during meiosis.

Question: 4. The synaptonemal complex has ____________ filaments.
Explanation: Explanation: There are 3 synaptonemal complexes, one central filament and 2 lateral filaments. The LC complex holds the central filament in line with lateral.

Question: 5. The fibers of the lateral filament are called____________
Explanation: Explanation: The lateral filament of synaptonemal complex consists of fibers called synaptomere. It is slightly wider than 10 nm.

Question: 6. Which of the following is incorrect about lateral filaments?
Option A: a) The lateral filaments are composed of chromatids
Option B: b) They can be spaced as much as 100-125 nm apart
Option C: c) The lateral filaments have DNA elements along with RNA and Proteins
Option D: d) The lateral filaments are connected by longitudinal connections
Explanation: Explanation: The two lateral elements have chromatids, i.e. they have DNA along with RNA and proteins. They are however connected via transverse elements or LC elements making a ladder like an arrangement.

Question: 7. During pairing of the chromosomes which of the following is not true?
Option A: a) There are 3 lateral filaments A, B, C
Option B: b) The A point pairs with adjacent A of other chromatid
Option C: c) The B point pairs with adjacent B of other chromatid
Option D: d) The C point pairs with C
Explanation: Explanation: The A point of the synapomere pairs with the A of adjacent synaptomere not chromatid. Only the B is connected to the other chromatid.

Question: 8. The zygosome has ________________ head and _________ tail connecting to the opposite zygosome.
Explanation: Explanation: The head of the zygosome is folded while the tail is straight. The sygosomes from opposite B points interact with each other via this tail portion.

Question: 9. The pairing of the chromosome is mediated by _______________ interactions.
Explanation: Explanation: The tails of two opposite zygosomes are oppositely charged. This brings about pairing by electrostatic interaction.

Question: 10. The synaptonemal complex is a portentous complex, which of the protein is not present in it?
Explanation: Explanation: Actin is a cytoskeletal element that doesnÕt participate in the syanptomenal complex formation. However, the other proteins mentioned and more may be present.

Question: 1.  The point where the synaptonemal complex is attached to nuclear envelope is called _______________
Explanation: Explanation: The alignment of the homologous chromosomes is made easier by the fact that the telomeres of the chromosome are frequently attached to the nuclear envelope. At these points of attachment, the SCs are linked by an electron dense thickening called the fixation plate.

Question: 2. Synaptonemal complex is shed in _______________ stage, from parts other than recombination site.
Explanation: Explanation: In the diplonema stage the SC is disintegrated from all points other than crossing over points. This leads to terminalization.

Question: 3. Which is the longest stage of spermatogenesis?
Explanation: Explanation: Pachytene stage of prophase 1 is the longest stage for spermatogenesis, which includes crossing over. It is a vital stage that leads to an increase in variability.

Question: 4. In an experiment you introduce a pair of unpaired homologous chromosomes into pachytene stage, what will you expect to observe?
Option B: b) Pairing will occur but no recombination
Option C: c) No pairing will occur but recombination will take place
Explanation: Explanation: There is no additional pairing or synaptonemal complex formation at the pachytene stage. Thus, the introduced chromosomes will neither pair, and in absence of it no recombination will occur.

Question: 6. What is the fate of nucleolus in pachytene?
Option B: b) Nucleolus appears like thin chromatin
Option D: d) Nucleolus remains attached to particular tetrad
Explanation: Explanation: During pachytene stage the nucleolus is not all together broken down. It remains attached to a particular tetrad.

Question: 8. Crossing over doesnÕt take place ________________
Explanation: Explanation: Crossing over can occur between two non-sister chromatids as well as for recombinational purpose. Crossing over also occurs between sister chromatids but it is of less significance as they have same genetic constitution. Three chromatids single cross over is not possible.

Question: 9. What is the stretch of DNA remaining unreplicated during pachytene?
Explanation: Explanation: In pachytene stage short stretches of DNA remains unreplicated. This is as short as 200bp. In zygotene stage the unreplicated chromosomes are about 104 bp.

Question: 10. Choose the wrong statement.
Option A: a) DNA replication in pachytene if prevented will lead to arm breakage
Option B: b) Replication in pachytene is delayed semiconservative replication
Option C: c) This replication sites are 200bp long
Option D: d) The DNA replication in pachytene can be inhibited by normal replication inhibiting agents
Explanation: Explanation: Pachytene DNA synthesis is not the continuation of a delayed semi-conservative replication of zygotene, but rather is related to a repair-replication system which closes up the broken ends of a Chromosome.

Question: 11. Electron dense bars located in the synaptonemal complex in pachytene is _________________
Explanation: Explanation: The recombination nodule is a multienzyme complex that is responsible for recombination of two chromatids. This appears as the electron dense region between two chromatids.

Question: 1.  The separation of the chromosomes in diplotene stage starts at _________________
Explanation: Explanation: The separation of the chromosomes in diplotene stage starts at the centromere and then proceeds towards the telomere. This process is called terminalization.

Question: 2. Homologous chromosomes in zygotene pair due to attraction and synaptonemal complex formation. Which of the following is true for diplotene phase?
Option A: a) The chromosomes still attract although synaptonemal complex degenerates
Option B: b) The synaptonemal complex persistes but chromosomes develop opposite charges
Option C: c) The chromosomes repel and completely separate
Option D: d) The synaptonemal complex breaks down
Explanation: Explanation: In the diplotene stage the chromosomes repel each other and synaptonemal complex breaks down. Repulsion canÕt be due to opposite charge but like charge, also they donÕt separate completely but are joined at the crossing over sites which gradually terminalize.

Question: 3. What is the normal number of chiasma seen in diplotene chromosomes?
Explanation: Explanation: The number of chiasmata is variable although it is usually 4, maximum number of chiasma may be 13-14. While some cells may have 1 chiasma other may have many more, 4 being the average.

Question: 4. In which of the following will you expect to see chiasma?
Explanation: Explanation: Achiasmatic meiosis has been reported in males of higher Diptera, Panorpa (scorpion fly), some grasshoppers and scorpions. It is also seen during oogenesis in Copepoda and Lepidoptera. However, female drosophila show recombination, hence chiasma.

Question: 5. Number of chiasma / total number of bivalent is________________
Explanation: Explanation: The following ratio is for the frequency of crossing over that shows how many cross over events take place / number of bivalent. The degree of terminalization on other hand is = number of terminalzed chromosome/ total number of bivalent.

Question: 6. According to Darlington terminalization process is brought about by ___________ force.
Explanation: Explanation: Darlington has shown that an electrostatic repulsive force acts between two pairs of chromatids. This leads to terminalization.

Question: 7.  Which of the following is wrong about diplotene?
Option A: a) Endoplasmic vesicles increase in the number
Option D: d) Chromosomes rotate by 180 degree to terminalize
Explanation: Explanation: The nucleolus disintegrates rather than condensing. It is on the way of disappearance of nucleolus. However, the other options are true.

Question: 9. The number of chiasma in diakinesis stage _________
Option D: d) There are no chiasma left
Explanation: Explanation: With the arrival of diktyotene stage the number of chiasma decreases and ultimately only the terminal chiasmas remain.

Question: 10. What is the bivalent shape in diakinesis?
Explanation: Explanation: The chromosome in diakynesis stage is O shaped as it is only connected in the terminal end and rest of the parts repel. The chromosome is also in its most condensed stage in this phase.

Question: 1.  Nuclear envelope breaks down finally in _____________
Explanation: Explanation: In the prometaphase the chromosome compaction reaches its maximum, recombination is complete, now the nuclear envelope breaks down and spindle fiber attaches to chromosomes.

Question: 2. Which of the following is true about the attachment of sister chromatid to kinetochore in this phase?
Option A: a) Each chromosome is bound by 2 spindle fibers at the kinetochore
Option C: c) The attachment is at centromere
Option D: d) Chromosomes bound by one spindle give negative signal to prevent cycle progression
Explanation: Explanation: In prometaphase 1 the homologous chromosome pair behaves as a single unit. In this case one spindle is attached to one chromosome as a pair and the chromosomes separate not chromatids.

Question: 3. The movement of the chromosome in metaphase is known as _______________
Explanation: Explanation: The two homologous chromosomes line up along the equatorial plate by the movement of congression. The two chromosomes here behave as 1 unit.

Question: 5. Choose the statement that doesnÕt agree with the metaphase 1?
Option A: a) Only one kinetochore is presented by 1 chromosome
Option B: b) Chromosomes are pulled apart by spindle fibers
Option C: c) There exists attraction between the homologous
Option D: d) They are lined along an equatorial plate
Explanation: Explanation: Although the homologous chromosomes are bound at the chiasma, their centromeres repel each other which assist separation to opposite pole.

Question: 6. The anaphase 1 shows which of the following?
Option A: a) Chromatids separate to one pole
Option C: c) The chromosomes separate to 4 cells
Option D: d) Each homologue reaches opposite pole
Explanation: Explanation: In anaphase 1 it is true that the homologous move to opposite pole. The result of meiosis is ultimately 4 cells but not by 1 division. The chromatids donÕt separate; centromere still binds the chromatids rather the chromosome separates at the chiasma interactions.

Question: 7. If your cell has 24 chromatids, what will be the number of a chromosome at each pole after anaphase 1?
Explanation: Explanation: 24 chromatids means there are 12 chromosmes. Anaphase 1 is reduction division so each homologue should move to opposite pole, resulting in reduction. Finally thus there will be only 6 chromosomes at each pole.

Question: 9. Which of the following agrees with telophase 1?
Option B: b) The sister chromatids of the bivalent is visible
Option C: c) The nuclear membrane breaks down
Option D: d) It is of very long duration
Explanation: Explanation: Telophase 1 is like a resting stop before meiosis 2, it is of rather short duration. The chromosomes remain compacted and the nuclear membrane is reformed. It is true that the chromosomes unlike mitosis are bivalent.

Question: 10. Choose the wrong statement out.
Option A: a) In most animals telophase 1 is absent
Option B: b) The chromosomes canÕt relax and are compacted
Option C: c) The cell passes into diffuse interphase
Explanation: Explanation: In telophase 1 the chromosomes relax even when compacted. The telophase may be absent in most animals and the cells do move into a diffuse interphase. The nuclear membrane is reformed only to disappear again at meiosis 2.

Question: 11. Which of the following will show telophase1?
Explanation: Explanation: Mangifera or mango is a dicot. Most animals like canines or us human beings donÕt have telophase 1. Monocot plant Trillium also lacks telophase 1.

Question: 12. The prophase 2 is ______________ mitotic prophase.
Explanation: Explanation: WE can call mitotic prophase and meiotic prophase 1 as similar not exactly the same. This is because the prophase here has bivalents that are much more condensed and the arms are widely separated.

Question: 13. Choose the statement that is not true for meiosis 2.
Option A: a) Doubled chromosomes line along equatorial plate
Option B: b) Karyokinesis is followed y cytokinesis
Option C: c) The chromosome number is reduced
Option D: d) The anaphase chromosomes start to spate from the centre
Explanation: Explanation: In meiosis 2 the chromosome number remains the same as this is not a reduction division. The meiosis 1 was the reduction division. Karyokinesis is followed by cytokinesis and the anaphase like mitotic anaphase has chromosomes separating starting at the centromere.

Question: 14. How many cells are produced by meiosis 2?
Explanation: Explanation: The number of cells formed at the end of the entire process of meiosis is 4, but only meiosis 2 produces 2 cells. Two such events of meiosis 2 on meiosis 1 end product ultimately gives 4 cells.

Question: 1.  Drosophila follows which of these modes of sex determination?
Explanation: Explanation: Drosophila follows the XY system of sex determination while other modes are seen in other animals. MM/NN or MN is a system of blood group and not a system of sex determination.

Question: 3. Which of the following is true for Drosophila sex determination?
Option A: a) Males are produced by presence of Y chromosome
Option B: b) Females are produced by presence of Y chromosome
Option C: c) Two X chromosome will always produce a female
Option D: d) Two Y chromosome will always produce a male
Explanation: Explanation: In Drosophila the sex is determined by the sex chromosome: set of autosome ratio. If X:A is 1 as in case of XX then itÕs a female, ratio of 0.5 in case of XY gives a male. The presence or even absence of Y chromosome makes little difference.

Question: 4. Which of these genes is responsible for the development of sex of Drosophila?
Explanation: Explanation: Sxl or sex lethal gene is responsible for the development of male or female characters in Drosophila. Other genes mentioned work in human beings.

Question: 5. The Sxl gene is turned ____________ by a ratio of _____________for X:A.
Explanation: Explanation: The Sxl gene is turned ON only when the ratio of X:A is 1, other times it is OFF. An OFF state produces a male while on state produces a female.

Question: 6. Sxl directly affects _____________
Explanation: Explanation: Sxl directly affects the splicing of tra pre-mRNA and produces a functional gene when Sxl is turned on. Downstream of this the female characters are produced. Xce is present in human and not in Drosophila.

Question: 7. Which of the following is a default pathway in Drosophila?
Explanation: Explanation: Development of male characters is like a default pathway in Drosophila which is turned off by female specific genes.

Question: 8. Which of the following will give a normal female Drosophila?
Explanation: Explanation: In the following case the X: A ratio is 1 which is required for developing female characters. In all the other cases viable female is not produced.

Question: 9. Genetic combination of AA : XYY in drosophila gives a _________
Explanation: Explanation: In this combination the X: A ratio is o.5 which will produce a male. Although there will be some problem in disjunction and male gamete production, otherwise the male is perfectly viable.

Question: 11. Which of the following is the correct pathway for developing female characters?
Option A: a) Sxl- SR- Tra- Dsx- Male gene repression
Option B: b) Sxl- Tra- SR- Dsx- Male gene repression
Option C: c) Sxl- Tra- Dsx- SR- Male gene repression
Option D: d) Sxl- SR- Dsx- Tra- Male gene repression
Explanation: Explanation: Functional Sxl proteins, controls the splicing of tra gene and produces functional Tra protein. Tra interacts with SR proteins controlling splicing of Dsx giving female specific DsxF which ultimately represses male specific characters.

Question: 1.  The XO system of sex determination is found in ______________
Explanation: Explanation: Insects have this XO system of sex determination. Thus it can be seen in Grasshopper, cockroaches, bees etc. Other options here have different modes of sex determination other than XO.

Question: 2. In case of XO system if an organism has AA+XO it will be a _______
Explanation: Explanation: In XO system presence of one copy of X chromosome produces a male, while there is no Y chromosome. Two copies give a female.

Question: 3. In XO system a male has a mother but not a _____________
Explanation: Explanation: The males are produced by parthenogenesis, i.e. by mitosis. While fertilization only takes place in case of a female child, only the two X chromosomes come together. Thus, the male has a mother but no father; they do however have a grandfather.

Question: 5. In ZZ/ZW system which of the following is true?
Option A: a) All organisms have ZZ chromosome
Option B: b) The chromosomes are shaped like Z
Explanation: Explanation: ZZ/ZW sex determination system is much like XX/XY system. However, in this case male is homozygous ZZ and female is heterozygous ZW. In this case to avoid confusion different notation is used and not because of the shape.

Question: 6. In ZZ/ZW system if there is a recessive Z allele carrying a distinct phenotype, it will have greater probability of expression in ____________
Option C: c) Recessive genes will not be expressed
Explanation: Explanation: Females being heterozygous will lack the compensating functional copy from other Z chromosomes will express it with greater probability. This is similar to the fact that X linked recessive disorder in mammals is expressed more in males.

Question: 7. Genic system of sex determination is seen in _______________
Explanation: Explanation: Yeast and other eukaryotic microorganism have this genic system of sex determination. In this case there is no special sex chromosome.

Question: 8. In bees the males are produced by _________
Explanation: Explanation: Bees have XO system of sex determination. In it the males are produced by parthenogenesis i.e. here is mitosis occurring in the mother that gives the zygote for male offspring.

Question: 10. Which of the following is true for a genic mode of sex determination?
Option A: a) It is seen in higher eukaryotes
Option C: c) XX will always give female in this case
Option D: d) It makes use of parthenogenesis for producing male offspring
Explanation: Explanation: Genic mode of sex determination is seen in eukaryotic microorganisms. In this case, there is no separate chromosome but allele at the gene locus determines sex.

Question: 11. In yeast the gene responsible for sex determination is ______________
Explanation: Explanation: In yeast, the genes at the MAT locus are responsible for determining the sex. Sex is mainly determined as mating factor and it alternates with every generation.

Question: 12. In yeast a MAT a type yeast can mate with __________
Explanation: Explanation: There are two mating types in yeast, MAT a and MAT alpha. Only yeast cells of opposite mating types can mate. In this case MAT, a can thus mate with MAT alpha. There is no MAT beta.

Question: 1.  Mammals have _______________ type of sex determination.
Explanation: Explanation: Like Drosophila mammals also have XX/ XY mode of sex determination. However, the mechanism of sex determination in this case is much different.

Question: 2. In Drosophila an organism with the genetic composition AA+XXY will be a normal female. What will be the case for mammal?
Explanation: Explanation: IN mammals unlike drosophila the presence of Y chromosome determines maleness, thus XXY will have male characters. Again the presence of additional X chromosome will give rise to some female characters resulting in klinefelter.

Question: 3. In mammals which of the following will be a Turner?
Explanation: Explanation: AA+ XO will be a turner. This condition the female characters are underdeveloped due to the absence of one X chromosome. AA+ XO/XY on the other hand is intersex.

Question: 5. The gene for sex determination in mammals is _________ and it is located in ___________
Explanation: Explanation: SRY is the gene in Y chromosome that is necessary for the development of male characters. It is located in the Y chromosome. The MAT is sex determining factor for yeast.

Question: 6. In an experiment, you add the short arm of Y chromosome to a cell line with composition AA+ XX. What will you see?
Option A: a) The cell rejects the Y chromosome
Option B: b) The cell develop female character
Option C: c) The cell develop male character
Option D: d) The cell develop neuter gender character
Explanation: Explanation: The short arm of the Y chromosome is carrying the SRY gene which determines the sex of the organism. Thus introduction of Y chromosome will promote the development of male characters.

Question: 7. Which of the following is wrong for sex chromosome?
Option A: a) X chromosome is larger than Y
Option D: d) All genes present on Y chromosome are unique to it
Explanation: Explanation: There is a homologous region between the X and Y chromosome, and genes in Y chromosome in that area is not unique to it. TDF is another name used for SRC gene that is also located on Y chromosome.

Question: 8. Klinefelter syndrome results due to ____________
Option A: a) Non-disjunction in the male gamete
Option B: b) Non-disjunction in the female gamete
Option D: d) Non-disjunction in any of the gametes
Explanation: Explanation: Klinefelter syndrome results from a genetic combination AA+ XXY; this can result from non-disjunction in either male or female gamete.

Question: 9. A person with a genetic composition AA+XYY composition. The non-disjunction is in the __________ parent and in _____________ meiotic division.
Explanation: Explanation: A female can never have Y chromosome to start with so the non-disjunction is in a male. If the non-disjunction was in 1st division improper segregation of X and Y will produce XY gamete. Here there is an improper 2nd division where 2Y generated in meiosis 2 moves to same pole giving YY gamete.

Question: 11. The intersex is produced by ________________
Option A: a) Fusion of a male and female zygote
Option B: b) Loss of X chromosome from some cells
Option C: c) Loss of Y chromosomes from some cells
Option D: d) Gain of X or Y chromosome due to non-disjunction
Explanation: Explanation: Intersex has the combination AA+ XO/XY. Presence of Y chromosomes develops male character so AA+XY cells are male. Absence of Y gives female characters so AA+XO gives female, this is due to loss of Y chromosome from these cells. Overall it results in intersex.

Question: 2.  An X linked recessive gene would appear to __________________
Option A: a) Be expressed in both males and females equally
Explanation: Explanation: Sex linked genes especially the sex linked recessive gene skips generations before expression. It is expressed more in males than female and is not necessarily lethal.

Question: 3. A Y linked gene ___________________
Option A: a) Is expressed only when homozygous
Option B: b) Is present near the telomere of long arm in human
Explanation: Explanation: A Y linked gene is expressed only in men and never in females as females lack a Y chromosome. It is not expressed in homozygous, rather in hemizygous for as its present only in a single copy. The region near that telomere is common for both sex chromosomes, so it is not sex linked.

Question: 4. Genes which are present in the homologous region of X and Y chromosomes are called______________
Explanation: Explanation: Genes present in the homologous region of X and Y chromosomes are known as partially sex linked. Although they are present on sex chromosome their inheritance pattern is like normal genes.

Question: 5. Choose the odd one out.
Explanation: Explanation: While the first three diseases are X linked recessive diseases, the last i.e. faulty tooth enamel and decolonization is a dominant trait.

Question: 7. In a family of four including a normal mother, a normal father, a color blind son and a normal son; who do you think has the defective X gene other than the affected son?
Explanation: Explanation: Males have only one X chromosome, so if the father or normal son carried the defective X gene they would show the phenotypic effect. Since the female has two copies of X chromosome, only in homozygous form the recessive gene like colorblindness is expressed. So mother here is a carrier.

Question: 8. A colorblind mother and a normal father give birth to a Klinefelter child with normal vision. Where do you think the non-disjunction has taken place?
Option B: b) 2nd meiotic division of the father
Explanation: Explanation: The non disjunction must be in the male parent as the child was not color blind. This is possible only if one X chromosome was normal which here came from father. Also as the disjunction produced XY and not two copies of same chromosome it must have been in 1st division.

Question: 9. If colorblindness was a dominant trait, which of the following would not be true?
Option A: a) It would be expressed in heterozygous females
Option B: b) It would be expressed in males
Option C: c) It would never be turned off
Option D: d) It would not skip generations
Explanation: Explanation: Due to dosage compensation X chromosomes are randomly turned off, so the mutant X could as well be turned off in heterozygote. Also it will affect every generation as it would be dominant. Option a and b are also true.

Question: 10. What is the probability that the son of a color blind father would be color blind?
Explanation: Explanation: Sons get the Y chromosome from father and the X from mother. So unless the mother is also a carrier, there is no probability of the son being colorblind.

Question: 11. Y linked inheritance is _______________ inheritance.
Explanation: Explanation: The inheritance pattern of Y linked gene is straight as it moves from father to son. Only males can inherit these traits.

Question: 12. Which of the following is wrong?
Option A: a) Y chromosome lacks dosage compensation
Option B: b) X linked genes are inherited as criss cross
Option C: c) Y linked gene like haemophilia passes from father to son
Option D: d) X linked recessive genes are carried by females
Explanation: Explanation: It is true that Y linked genes pass from father to son, but Haemophilia is not a Y linked gene. It is a recessive X linked gene.

Question: 13. Which of the following is a Y linked gene?
Explanation: Explanation: Among the following options only hypertrichosis is a Y linked gene. It is the presence of hair in the ear. It follows the Y linked rule of inheritance.

Question: 14. Which of the following is partially sex linked?
Explanation: Explanation: While red green colorblindness is an X linked recessive trait. Complete colorblindness however is a partially sex linked gene in man.

Question: 15. A turner child born to normal parents is haemophilic. Where did the non-disjunction occur?
Explanation: Explanation: The only possibility here is that the mother was a carrier. The egg received this defective X chromosome from mother and no sex chromosome from the father. Thus, there was non disjunction in the father. The resultant child was AA+ XÕO. (XÕ=mutant).

Question: 1.  Both Drosophila and mammals have XY system of sex determination. Dosage compensation y inactivation of one X chromosome is seen in ___________________
Explanation: Explanation: Only in case of mammals dosage compensation mechanism is by inactivation of one X chromosome. In Drosophila there is a different mechanism.

Question: 2. Barr bodies are found ________________
Option A: a) In the cytoplasm of female
Option B: b) In the nuclei of female
Option C: c) In the cytoplasm of male
Option D: d) In the nuclei of male
Explanation: Explanation: The inactivated X chromosome in female forms a highly condensed structure called the Barr body which is found in the nuclei. As male have only one X chromosome is no inactivation and no Barr body.

Question: 4. If a chromosome loses its XIC due to deletion it will_______________________
Explanation: Explanation: XIC is X inactivation centre, only one X with XIC stays active in a cell. Now is a chromosome loses is XIC that will not be counted as X chromosome and will stay active.

Question: 5. Due to the translocation process, the XIC from one X chromosome in a woman passed to chromosome 3. The individual died. What were the probable reasons of death?
Option A: a) The X chromosome was unable to show its effect
Option B: b) Both X chromosome being active too much gene product was produced
Explanation: Explanation: As XIC translocated to chromosome 3 now it can be counted as an X chromosome. In some cells randomly this chromosome 3 is condensed and inactivated which prevents the important autosomal gene product from being formed. Thus the individual dies.

Question: 6. Lysonization takes place ____________
Explanation: Explanation: Lysonization process takes place in the 15th day after fertilization when the embryo is 500-1000 cell stage. This inactivated one X chromosome in each cell.

Question: 7. _____________________ determines which X chromosome remains active.
Explanation: Explanation: XCE or X controlling element that is present in the XIC region determines which X chromosome will be inactivated.

Question: 8. Which one of the following is the only active gene in the inactivated X chromosome?
Explanation: Explanation: The X inactive specific transcript (XIST in humans/ Xist in mice) gene, is located in the XIC, itÕs expressed exclusively from the inactive X chromosome, producing a 17 kb non-coding RNA that is not translated. Ribosome genes are in nucleolus.

Question: 10. XIST mRNA coats the inactive X and calls in _____________
Explanation: Explanation: Histone deacetylases lead to the removal of acetyl group from specific histone residues. This leads to exposure of positive charges on then and causes stronger binding. Specific methylase also plays similar role. Together they help in heterochromatin formation.

Question: 11. Tortoise shell or calico cats are always ________________ for O locus that is responsible for orange color development.
Explanation: Explanation: The O gene is responsible for orange color development. Only dominant O can express it over the mutant B gene that causes black color. O gene is located in X chromosome. Thus in heterozygous condition if O carrying X chromosome is inactivated it leads to black patch as seen here.

Question: 12. Calico cats are always______________
Explanation: Explanation: In calico cats there is development of black and orange and white patches. This is possible only when the dominant O allele is turned off in some X chromosome due to dosage compensation. As males have only one X chromosome they are never turned off. Thus, only females show this trait.

Question: 13. The XXY klinefelter survive but trisomy in most autosome is lethal. Why?
Option B: b) Autosomes have better dominant recessive relations
Option D: d) Autosomes are more in number
Explanation: Explanation: Due to dosage compensation only one X chromosome in XXY says active. So the effect of excess X chromosome is somewhat mitigated. In autosome there is no such inactivation and excess of gene products leads to lethality.

Question: 14. Which one of the following is true for Drosophila?
Option A: a) They donÕt have X chromosome
Option B: b) One of the female X chromosome is inactivated
Option C: c) The male Y chromosome is inactivated
Option D: d) The male X chromosome is hyper active
Explanation: Explanation: In Drosophila, dosage compensation is achieved in a different way. The maleÕs X chromosome appears to be hyperactivated, allowing it to be transcribed at twice the rate of either X chromosome in the female.

Question: 1.  The sex influenced traits are present in _______________________
Explanation: Explanation: Sex influenced traits are present in the autosomes. They are not present in the sex chromosome; although their expression is dependent on the sex of the individual.

Question: 3. If A is a sex influenced trait that is more expressed in males, then which of the following is false?
Option A: a) Only male having a homozygous recessive form of this gene will not express it
Option B: b) No female will express the gene
Option D: d) Heterozygous female will not express this gene
Explanation: Explanation: If the sex influenced trait is more expressed in men then it acts as a dominant trait in men. And at the same time, it acts as a recessive trait in female. The female with homozygous form of this trait will thus express it, and men lacking any copy of it in case of recessive homozygote will not express it.

Question: 4. If present of horn in a breed of sheep is due to the presence of h+ allele which is sex influenced and more expressed in male, choose the off one out.
Explanation: Explanation: This sex influenced trait is dominant for male and recessive for female. Out of the given options only heterozygous female will not express this trait making it the off one.

Question: 5. Patterned baldness is a sex influenced trait more expressed in a male. If b+ is normal allele making non-bald phenotype and b is mutant leading to bald phenotype, for a cross between a bald mother and normal father, what is the probability of a bald son?
Explanation: Explanation: Baldness is a sex influenced trait, so the mother is certainly b/b and the father is b+,b+. So, the son will get at least one baldness allele from the mother. Heterozygous male expresses the sex influenced trait; hence the son will definitely be bald.

Question: 7. Choose the odd one out on the basis of sex influence.
Explanation: Explanation: All the mentioned options are sex influenced traits. Cleft palate, Club foot and Gout are dominant for males while osteoporosis is dominant for females.

Question: 8. What will be the phenotype and genotype of a daughter born to bald mother and non-bald father?
Explanation: Explanation: Baldness is a dominant gene for a male. A bald mother is thus homozygous for the allele; at least one baldness gene will thus pass to offspring from her. The father is normal so he must lack any baldness allele and a normal gene will pass from him. Hence daughter is a heterozygote and normal.

Question: 9. Which one of the following will not be expressed in female even in homozygous form?
Explanation: Explanation: Cock feathering is a sex limited trait which is expressed only on one sex depending. Even if the other sex is homozygous for it, the phenotype will not be expressed unless there is serious hormonal change.

Question: 10. If a bull doesnÕt express the milking factor, where m+ is normal and m is a mutant gene, its genotype is?
Explanation: Explanation: Milking factor is a sex influenced trait that is only expressed in females i.e. cows. Bulls will never express these genes irrespective of their phenotype. Hence, their genotype canÕt be specified.

Question: 11. Appearance of cock feather in chicken is ________________
Explanation: Explanation: This gene is located in the autosome so itÕs not X or Y linked. Cock feathering will not be seen in hen even when it is homozygous, hence itÕs not sex influenced. Thus, it is sex limited trait.

Question: 12. Sex influenced genes will not occur in ________________
Option B: b) Homologous part of sex chromosome
Option C: c) Short arm of human Y chromosome
Explanation: Explanation: Short arm of human Y chromosome is not homologous to X chromosome. Thus, genes there will show Y linkage. Sex influenced genes donÕt show linkage and are not exclusive to X or Y chromosomes, so it will not be present there.

Question: 1.  In incomplete dominance__________________
Option A: a) Phenotype of both allele is expressed
